column11:
Buy the BeagleBoard-xM

Please visit the BeagleBoard-xM product purchase page at http://beagleboard.org/buyxM.

Join or start a Beagle Board related project

Please register your project on code.google.com and use tag "beagleboard".

  • Currently Registered Projects

Beagle Board Tools

The Beagle Board is meant for hobbyists, students, open source developers, and as a supplement to software development on the TI EVM. The package would contain a board, a USB cable for power and monitor-style debug, and information on returns/replacements with a pointer to http://BeagleBoard.org. All of the tools would be linked for free download from the website and we can add links to professional tools as well. The free tools will include the Code Sourcery ARM Linux compiler, a C64x+ compiler, and some bootloading tools. Binary images will be provided for graphics development at some point.

Texas Instruments and University of Texas BeagleBoard Open Source Challenge

For details about the challenge, visit www.ti.com/beagleboardchallenge.

Available for download here are:

  • the SD card image for the BeagleBoard training
  • the training slides in PDF

Note: The above SD card image and slides

Reflash the boards

A general backgrounder on booting the BeagleBoard can be found at http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-beagle-board/. There are also a handful of troubleshooting tips at http://www.angstrom-distribution.org/demo/beagleboard/

The boards did have an old bootloader in the flash and the cards have a buggy u-boot.bin. To update the flash to work around the issue

Ah hah! It seems to think the USER button is pressed. I remember that u-boot bug. It is fixed in a newer u-boot
column44:
but we can hack in a fix by loading boot.scr instead of user.scr.

Here's the last set of commands to type into u-boot

Type in the last two commands now to set the boot command. This will cause your board to always look for boot.scr on the SD card.

OMAP3 beagleboard.org # setenv bootcmd 'mmc init;run loadbootscript; run bootscript'OMAP3 beagleboard.org # saveenvSaving Environment to NAND...Erasing Nand...Erasing at 0x260000 -- 100% complete.Writing to Nand... done

If you reboot now
column45:
you should no longer get the ugly "(none) login:" that comes from running a ramdisk image that is too big to fit into memory.

If you don't have both a serial port and cable

It is likely possible to fix the SD card to enable booting all the time when holding the USER button by replacing either the u-boot.bin file or the user.scr file. The quickest hack would be to copy boot.scr to user.scr in the FAT partition on the card
column46:
then simply power-up holding the USER button and release it when the boot starts.

Happy hacking!!

"

Flashing X-Loader and U-Boot

  • Load u-boot.out (ELF file format) using CCS.
  • Flash X-Loader using U-Boot (Send the attached X-Loader with Kermit).
loadb 0x80200000 115200;onenand unlock 0 0;onenand unlock 1 0;onenand unlock 2 0;onenand unlock 3 0;onenand erase block 0-3;onenand write 80200000 0 2000;
  • Flash U-Boot using U-Boot (Send the attached U-Boot with Kermit).
loadb 0x80300000 115200onenand unlock 4 0;onenand unlock 5 0;onenand erase block 4-5;onenand write 80300000 80000 40000;
  • Close CCS and remove board power.
  • Remove EMU0 short.
  • Power the board and observe U-Boot prompt.

Flashing Kernel and File System

Here are the tested ONENAND commands and addresses to flash kernel and ramdisk image.
  • Flash the Kernel (Send the attached uImage with Kermit).
loadb 0x80300000 115200;onenand unlock 7 0;onenand unlock 8 0;onenand unlock 9 0;onenand unlock 10 0;onenand unlock 11 0;onenand unlock 12 0;onenand unlock 13 0;onenand unlock 14 0;onenand unlock 15 0;onenand unlock 16 0;onenand unlock 17 0;onenand unlock 18 0;onenand unlock 19 0;onenand unlock 20 0;onenand unlock 21 0;onenand unlock 22 0;onenand erase block 7-22;onenand write 80300000 e0000 1D0000;
Use a RAMDISK initialized by the ONENAND
  • Flash the RAMDISK file system (Send the attached ramdisk_ext2.gz with Kermit.)
loadb 0x81600000 115200;onenand unlock 23 0;onenand unlock 24 0;onenand unlock 25 0;onenand unlock 26 0;onenand unlock 27 0;onenand unlock 28 0;onenand unlock 29 0;onenand unlock 30 0;onenand unlock 31 0;onenand unlock 32 0;onenand unlock 33 0;onenand unlock 34 0;onenand unlock 35 0;onenand unlock 36 0;onenand unlock 37 0;onenand unlock 38 0;onenand unlock 39 0;onenand unlock 40 0;onenand unlock 41 0;onenand unlock 42 0;onenand unlock 43 0;onenand unlock 44 0;onenand unlock 45 0;onenand unlock 46 0;onenand unlock 47 0;onenand unlock 48 0;onenand erase block 23-48;onenand write 81600000 2E0000 300000;
  • Configure U-Boot to load the kernel and file system.
setenv bootargs 'console=tty0 console=ttyS0

column11:
Recommended BeagleBoard Peripherals

How do I know what peripherals I need or want?

Power

At a minimum, you need power. There are a few ways you can power a BeagleBoard, BeagleBoard-xM or BealgeBone. You have an option to feed the on-board regulators through either the 5V barrel connector input or USB input. When powered up over USB, the regulators are somewhat limited in what they can supply the system. Power over USB is sufficient as long as the software and system you are running performs some management to keep it under the USB current limit threshold. For simplicity and maximum capability, powering over the 5V barrel connector is typically recommended.

Specific recommendations

5V power supplies

The power adapter needs to provide 5V over a 5.5mm outer diameter and 2.1mm inner diameter barrel connector. A barrel connector length of 9.5mm is more than sufficient. The currently recommended supply current is at least 1.2A (or 6W)
column12:
but at least 2A (or 10W) is recommended if you are going to connect up anything over the USB. The actual power consumption will vary greatly with changes on the USB load. Below are some recommended units:

  • Digi-Key-supplied PHIHONG USA PSC12R-050 - Be sure to get the right adapter for your country

I also recommend searching for power adapters on delicious.com and personally tagging any that you find useful
column13:
either already on that list or not already on that list.

LCD

There are several options for getting an LCD to add-on to your BeagleBoard or BeagleBoard-xM.

  • For the BeagleBoard-xM
column14:

column11:
Linux and u-boot sources

The Linux kernel sources for the BeagleBoard, BeagleBoard-xM and BeagleBone are maintained on Github.com/BeagleBoard. The U-Boot bootloader sources maintained as part of the U-Boot mainline on git.denx.de.

The production and validation of these kernels is done with the Angstrom Distribution and meta-beagleboard with the OpenEmbedded build system. The sources shared here are done for convenience for those familiar with the git version control system.

For instructions on building for the Debian system (armhf) using an Ubuntu 12.04 host system
column12:
see this blog post.

Example for installing toolchain

~$ wget http://www.angstrom-distribution.org/toolchains/angstrom-2011.03-x86_64-linux-armv7a-linux-gnueabi-toolchain-qte-4.6.3.tar.bz2~$ sudo tar -C / -xjf angstrom-2011.03-x86_64-linux-armv7a-linux-gnueabi-toolchain-qte-4.6.3.tar.bz2~$ export PATH=/usr/local/angstrom/arm/bin:$PATH

Example build procedure for BeagleBone MLO and u-boot

~$ git clone git://git.denx.de/u-boot.git && cd u-boot~/u-boot$ CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- make am335x_evm

Example build procedure for BeagleBone 3.8-rcX kernel

~$ git clone git://github.com/beagleboard/kernel.git && cd kernel~/kernel$ git checkout 3.8~/kernel$ ./patch.sh~/kernel$ cp configs/beaglebone kernel/arch/arm/configs/beaglebone_defconfig~/kernel$ wget http://arago-project.org/git/projects/?p=am33x-cm3.git\;a=blob_plain\;f=bin/am335x-pm-firmware.bin\;hb=HEAD -O kernel/firmware/am335x-pm-firmware.bin~/kernel$ cd kernel~/kernel/kernel$ mkdir rootfs~/kernel/kernel$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- beaglebone_defconfig~/kernel/kernel$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- -j4 uImage dtbs~/kernel/kernel$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- -j4 modules~/kernel/kernel$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- INSTALL_MOD_PATH=$HOME/kernel/kernel/rootfs modules_install~/kernel/kernel$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- uImage-dtb.am335x-bone~/kernel/kernel$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi- uImage-dtb.am335x-boneblack

Building a kernel module

I applied this patch and that provided the following files:

~/kernel/kernel/hello/hello.c

#include        /* Needed by all modules */#include        /* Needed for KERN_INFO */#include          /* Needed for the macros */static int __init hello_start(void){    printk(KERN_INFO "Loading hello module...
");    printk(KERN_INFO "Hello world
");    return 0;}static void __exit hello_end(void){    printk(KERN_INFO "Goodbye Mr.
");}module_init(hello_start);module_exit(hello_end);

~/kernel/kernel/hello/Makefile

obj-m := hello.oPWD   := $(shell pwd)KDIR  := ${PWD}/..default:    make -C $(KDIR) SUBDIRS=$(PWD) modules 
~/kernel/kernel$ cd hello~/kernel/kernel/hello$ make ARCH=arm CROSS_COMPILE=arm-angstrom-linux-gnueabi-
"

column11:
Future home of BeagleBoard.org

The Beagle Board is a low-cost, fan-less single-board computer based on Texas Instruments' OMAP35x device family
column12: with all of the expandability of today's desktop machines
column14: expense
column15:
or noise.

We are in the phase of hand-selecting early adopters to receive the limited number of boards we have. Please subscribe to the mailing list to get notification of when we will begin to take orders. There is also an early-adopter request e-mail address that you can find by looking at the mailing list archives (revb-request).

When boards go on sale
column16: they will be available for $149 (plus shipping) via a link from this page.  We will be utilizing a world-wide distributor with reach for most countries.  Initial availability will be for Rev. B boards
column17: with support for a single USB port (OTG).  Rev. C boards will add support for an additional USB port (EHCI)
column18: enabling the use of one USB port for power and another port to act as a USB host.  The Rev. B boards may use the USB port to provide power to the board or to act as a USB host
column19:
but not both at the same time. There is a 5V power connector on the board for when you want to use the USB port in host mode.

column11:
About BeagleBoard.org and the BeagleBoard.org Foundation

The BeagleBoard.org Foundation is a Michigan,USA-based 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation existing to provide education in and collaboration around the design and use of open-source software and hardware in embedded computing. BeagleBoard.org provides a forum for the owners and developers of open-source software and hardware to exchange ideas, knowledge and experience. The BeagleBoard.org community collaborates on the development of open source physical computing solutions including robotics, personal manufacturing tools like 3D printers and laser cutters, and other types of industrial and machine controls.

BeagleBoard.org is the result of an effort by a collection of passionate individuals
column12: including several employees of Texas Instruments
column14: open
column15: and embedded devices. We invite you to participate     and become part of BeagleBoard.org
column16:
defining its direction.

Support for BeagleBoard.org boards comes from the very active development community through this website
column18: and the IRC channel. Original production funding was provided by Digi-Key
column20: but distribution has now     been opened up to dozens of distributors across the world. On-going funding    for board prototypes has been provided by manufacturing partners. Texas     Instruments generously allows Jason Kridner
column21: community manager    and software cat herder
column22: to spend time    to provide support and development of the BeagleBoard.org project as part of    their duties at TI. Manufacturing partners pay volume prices for the TI (and all other)    components. BeagleBoard.org licenses the use of BeagleBoard.org logos    for use as part of the <a href="http://beagleboard.org/logo">Manufacturer
column23: Compliant and Compatible logo programs . BeagleBoard.org also participates as a mentoring organization for Google Summer of Code which pays a small fee for mentoring students. The first five BeagleBoard.org designs (BeagleBoard
column25: BeagleBone
column26:
BeagleBone Black and BeagleBoard-X15) where all executed by BeagleBoard.org co-founder Gerald Coley of EmProDesign.

All the designs are fully open source and components are available for anyone to manufacture compatible hardware. We do request contact and permission before considering the use of the BeagleBoard.org name on any products.

The boards are low-cost
column27: fan-less single-board computers based on low-power     Texas Instruments processors featuring the ARM Cortex-A series core with     all of the expandability of today's desktop machines
column31: development was targeted at enabling Linux    distributions to improve support for ARM devices. With tremendous success    and support by numerous Linux distributions
column32: development has become more    focused on enabling simplified physical computing on advanced GUI-enabled    and/or networked-enabled devices with a super-simple out-of-box learning    experience and support for development environments familiar to just about    every developer
column36:
Android and web tools to bare metal and even Arduino/Wiring-style programming.

How to Enter

  1. Submit an original cape design. Minimum requirements:

  2. Upload your project to an online file sharing site (ex: Google Drive

AdaFruit

Adafruit has one of the largest collections of free electronics tutorials
column12: open-source hardware and software to help educate and inspire 		the next generation of scientists and engineers. Limor and her company 		Adafruit are pioneers in open-source hardware and software - from the 		start of the company the designs and code created have been given away 		freely for others to learn from and build their own businesses. By 		giving away the "recipes" young people and educators can learn how to 		design
column13:
build and manufacture their own creations.

CircuitCo

Circuitco Electronics is a printed circuit solutions provider with offices in the USA and Europe. Our services include Hardware and Software Engineering and final proto and production assembly. Circuitco is a pioneer in Open Source Hardware development. We are the original manufacturers of the Beagleboard line of product. We also have Engineered and built many custom product ideas based on OSH designs for community members and organizations. Our newest line of product for Beaglebone are the Beagle Capes. Capes are add on boards that increase the functionality of the Beaglebone. We have a large offering of Capes that include various size LCDs
column14:
Camera and WIFI modules to name a few. These capes are sold via our e-commerce site www.boardzoo.com and at all major franchised distributors.

Mouser

As a strategic partner of Texas Instruments
column15: Mouser Electronics 		stocks the widest selection of TIs newest components and development 		tools and provides same-day quick shipping to its customers across the 		globe on most orders received by 8 pm US CST. Mousers website is 		updated daily and searches millions of products to locate orderable part 		numbers available for easy online purchase. Mouser.com also houses 		technical design information

column11:
BeagleBoard Product Details

The USB-powered BeagleBoard is a low-cost
column12: fan-less single board computer that unleashes laptop-like performance and expandability without the bulk
column14:
or noise of typical desktop machines.

OMAP3530 processor highlights:

  • Over 1
column15:
200 Dhrystone MIPS using the superscalar ARM Cortex-A8 with highly accurate branch prediction and 256KB L2 cache running at up to 600MHz
  • OpenGL© ES 2.0 capable 2D/3D graphics accelerator capable of rendering 10 million polygons per second
  • HD video capable TMS320C64x+ DSP for versatile signal processing at up to 430MHz
  • USB power via complete chip-set with minimal additional power-consuming logic

    • Expansion capability and power options to satisfy your imagination:

    • DVI-D for connecting digital computer monitors
    • Compatibility with a huge collection of USB peripherals including hubs
column16: keyboards
column21:
and much more
  • MMC+/SD/SDIO interface for memory or wireless connectivity
  • S-Video out for connecting your NTSC or PAL television or wearable visor
  • Stereo audio in and out for a microphone and headphones or speakers
  • Power via typical USB chargers for cell phones from your laptop
column24:
or even from a solar backpack

Community driven support and expertise:

  • Contact hundreds of developers today via the mailing list and live IRC discussion channel
  • Discover projects currently using the BeagleBoard
  • eLinux Wiki Entry

Specifications and Other Resources

  • Current Board Hardware Reference Manual
  • Design Materials
  • Digi-Key Product Training Module

Verified BeagleBoard Peripherals

the entry forms and submission must be made in the official language of the country.

column16: 2012 at 11:59 p.m. (PST). No submissions submitted after December 31

column20:

entrants must be eighteen (18) year of age or older.

Entries must be submitted by the deadline to be considered. Participants will not be allowed to change or supplement their submissions once they have been submitted.
  • All entrants agree to follow and abide by the design idea requirements and judging criteria.
  • All entrants warrant and represent that all design ideas and applications submitted are entirely original and that entrant is the owner of all interests in and rights to such designs. This representation is a requirement of participation in the contest. By clicking "I agree

as part of the online submission, all entrants represent that there is no third party of any kind, whether an academic institution, commercial company, individual, or governmental legal entity which has any proprietary or other interest in, claims or rights to, any intellectual property rights, including trade secret, know-how, copyright, patent, trademark or trade name, in any design ideas submitted under the contest.

All entrants agree to obtain any necessary clearance or approval from any necessary third party participation in all contest activities and any such approvals which are required as a condition of participation.
  • No confidential relationship is established between the Sponsors and the entrant as a result of entering this contest. None of the information submitted by the participants will be treated by the Sponsors as trade secrets, confidential information, or as protected data under any obligation.

Entrant hereby agrees that the Designs shall be subject to the Creative Commons 3.0 Attribution License. The Designs are protected by copyright and/or other applicable law. Any use of the Designs other than as authorized under the Creative Commons 3.0 Attribution License or copyright law is prohibited.

Winners agree to supply Sponsors with any information necessary for tax reporting purposes and to cooperate in fulfilling all applicable legal requirements.
  • The entrant whose design idea is chosen for consideration for any award, as a condition of award, may be required to submit further information concerning employment and residence. Also, as a condition of award, the entrant may be required to sign (i) other documents necessary to ensure non-exclusive license right to TI, for such design ideas, and (ii) a liability/publicity release.
  • The non-exclusive license to TI of intellectual property rights, as described herein is free of charge and without remuneration of any kind. All entrants agree that the opportunity to compete for prizes, receive publicity, and increase ones understanding of TI products represents full and adequate consideration for license of these rights by all participants. Prizes do not represent fixed-sum monetary remuneration of the licensing of intellectual property and rights in design submissions.
  • All entrants grant the Sponsors the right to publicize their names, likeness, any information provided on the entry form or their design idea entry in whatever manner without reservation or compensation. In certain countries, due to local requirements, it may be necessary for entrants to execute, in addition to this entry form, certain other documents for license of intellectual property rights, prior to any publication of the full design idea submission. In those countries, TI will make appropriate arrangements. Entries and design submissions may be published in Sponsor or third party publications.
  • Entrants will not be reimbursed for any costs incurred or for efforts expended in connection with their participation in the contest. Such costs are the responsibility of the participants.
  • NO PURCHASE IS NECESSARY.
  • Decisions by the contest judges are final. The Sponsors reserve the right to refrain from awarding any prize if there are no or minimal qualified entries.
  • PRIZES: Total approximate value of all prizes: $1,000  USD
    • Grand Prize
      • Three (3) winning cape Design entrants will have their Designs prototyped and have at least one (1) production lot manufactured and sold through CircuitCo or CircuitCo's designated distributor. In the event that a winning cape Design is deemed marketable and sufficient distributor interest is generated, CircuitCo will continue to manufacture the cape Design for distribution.
      • Additionally, each cape Design winner will receipt $500 USD from TI and $500 USD from Mouser Electronics.
      • Finally, each cape Design winner will receive their choice of one of the following tools from Total Phase: (1) a Beagle USB 480 Protocol Analyzer, (2) an I2C/SPI Kit or (3) a CAN/I2C Kit.
      • Additional third party sponsor prizes may also be awarded.
    • Winners will be announced via media outlets and BeagleBoard.org.
    • In addition to the Grand Prize, weekly drawings will be held in which third party prizes will be awarded.
  • In the event of unavailability of any of the stated prizes, Sponsors reserve the right to substitute items of equal or greater value.
  • If a winner cannot be reached within (10) days of notification, or if a prize is returned with no forwarding address, the Sponsors reserve the right to deem the prize forfeited. The prize will then be awarded to the runner(s)-up for the applicable prize.
  • Employees and agents of the Sponsors and such individuals immediate family (including spouse, parents, siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, step-children, step-parents and in-laws) and member of the same household are prohibited from entering this contest.
  • THE CONTEST SHALL BE CONSIDERED VOID WHERE, AND TO THE EXTENT, PROHIBITED BY LAW.
  • Sponsors reserve the right to use information regarding contestants for future mailings subject to applicable laws and regulations and privacy policies. Texas Instruments privacy policy can be found at www.ti.com/home_f_privacy.
  • The Designs will be judged and voted on by a panel consisting of sponsor representatives. In order to be eligible

column11:
Winning BeagleBone Cape Plug-In Board Designs


The judges tirelessly reviewed each and every innovative BeagleBone Cape Plug-in Board design entry and have chosen the three winning submissions.

Drum roll
column12:
please...

The winning entries are Replicape by Elias Bakken
column13:
Interacto by Chris Clark and the Geiger cape by Matt Ranostay.

Congratulations Elias
column14: Chris and Matt! You each get $500 from Texas Instruments
column15: $500 from Mouser and a tool from Total Phase. Plus
column16: your amazing winning designs will be prototyped
column17:
manufactured and sold through Circuitco Electronics.

In addition to the grand prize winners
column18: our sponsors graciously agreed to give prizes to the social media favorite - the design that received the highest number of Likes
column19: +1's and Tweets. The social media favorite is the FPGA LOGI-BONE by Michael Jones. Michael
column20: you get a tool from Total Phase
column21:
an AM335x StarterKit from Mouser and a Proto Cape Kit from Adafruit.

Thank you to everyone that entered the first ever BeagleBone Cape Plug-in Board Design Contest. Your innovative and creative entries made this contest a success. You are inspiring and it is because of you the Beagle platform exists.

Here are the winning cape designs...

Grand Prize

Replicape by Elias Bakken

Replicape is a 3D printer cape which includes

  • 5 stepper motors (X
column25:
Ext2)
  • 3 high power MOSFETs (PWM controlled) for 2 extruders and 1 HPB
  • 3 medium power MOSFETs (PWM controlled) for up to 3 fans
  • 3 analog input ports for thermistors
  • 3 inputs for end stops (X
column27:
Z)
  • Programmable current limits on steppers motor drivers (SMD). No need to manually adjust a pot meter.
  • Microstepping individually programmable for each SMD from 1 to 32.
  • X
column28:
Y and Ext 1 SMDs wired to PRUICSS for hard real time operation.
  • Option for stackable LCD cape Grand Prize

     Interacto by Chris Clark

    Get your BeagleBone interactive with

    • a triple axis accelerometer
    • gyroscope
    • magnetometer
    • plus
column29:
a 640x480 30fps camera

All sensors are digital and communicate via I2C to the BeagleBone. The camera frames are captured using the PRU.

Grand Prize

Geiger cape by Matt Ranostay

Geiger cape is a working design that registers radiation counts from background sources and test sources. BOM cost for the Geiger Cape is well under $60 if you exclude any fancy geiger tubes or bring your own. Everyone in this project contributions:

  • Matt Ranostay - QA Tester/HW reworker
column32:
Presentation Giver at ELCE 2012
  • Pantelis Antoniou (TI Consultant) - Capebus support added for Geiger Cape
  • Dimitris Sapountzakis - Primary hardware design

    • There are few board erratas that exist. These mostly have to with protecting users from toasting the beaglebone
column33:
and some package sizing. But this is a completely working design with multiple geiger tubes.

Social Media Favorite

FPGA LOGI-BONE by Michael Jones The FPGA LOGI-BONE is a high performance low cost FPGA expansion board specifically designed to interface with the BeagleBone as an FPGA cape. The LOGI-BONE meets the requirements of being low cost while maintaining maximum performance. The LOGI-BONE facilitates maximum expansion using standardized interfaces including PMOD modules
column34: SATA devices and Arduino Shields to allow direct plug and play functionality with a diverse amount of available hardware. The PCB was designed using a 4 layer PCB with utmost care taken to length tune and impedance control critical high speed signals. The LOGI-BONE has versatile programming options making it easy to design and program custom FPGA applications. "

column11:
The Next BeagleBone is BeagleBone Black.

The new dog is out of his cage!

Everything you love about the original BeagleBone and more:

  • Half the price: $45
  • Higher performance with TIs 1GHz Sitara AM335x ARM® Cortex-A8 processor
  • On-board HDMI to connect directly to TVs and monitors
  • More and faster memory now with DDR3
  • On-board flash storage frees up the microSD card slot
  • Support for existing Cape plug-in boards

Plus
column12:
it's sporting an all-new color just in time for spring!

It's available now! Go to the BeagleBone Black page to find out more and to purchase from your favorite distributor.

Also
column13: if you're at Design West this week
column14:
you have an opportunity to win one and see it in action. Click here for more info.

"

DESIGN WEST BEAGLEBONE BLACK ON-SITE GIVEAWAY CONTEST RULES

For purposes of these Rules, TI shall mean Texas Instruments, Inc and its subsidiaries, Circuitco shall mean Circuitco Electronics LLC and its subsidiaries, element 14 shall mean Premier Farnell plc and its subsidiaries and Mouser shall mean Mouser Electronics, Inc and its subsidiaries. TI, Circuitco, element 14 and Mouser are collectively referred to herein as the Sponsors.
  1. To be eligible to compete, each entrant must read and agree to abide by the Contest rules.
  2. Each entrant must willingly surrender a business card. The business card is considered the official entry form to this contest. Submitting a Twitter handle is optional and doubles the entrants chances of winning.
  3. Entries must be in English.
  4. Phase one of the Contest begins on April 23, 2013 at 1:00 p.m. (PDT) and ends April 23, 2013 at 7:00 p.m. (PDT). No submissions submitted after April 23, 2013 at 2:00 p.m. (PDT) will be considered. Phase 1 award recipients will be contacted before 7:00 p.m. (PDT) on April 23, 2013 and will have until 4:00 p.m. (PDT) April 25, 2013 to claim their prize from the element 14 booth. Texas Instruments reserves the right to cancel this Contest phase before the end date at its sole discretion, and decline to award prizes if there are no eligible entrants.
  5. Phase two of the Contest begins on April 24, 2013 at 12:00 p.m. (PDT) and ends April 24, 2013 at 5:30 p.m. (PDT). No submissions submitted after April 24, 2013 at 1:00 p.m. (PDT) will be considered. Phase 2 award recipients will be contacted before 5:30 p.m. (PDT) on April 24, 2013 and will have until 4:00 p.m. (PDT) April 25, 2013 to claim their prize from the Mouser Booth. Texas Instruments reserves the right to cancel this Contest phase before the end date at its sole discretion, and decline to award prizes if there are no eligible entrants.
  6. Multiple entries per person are allowed, but only one business card submission and one Twitter handle submission per Contest phase will be accepted.
  7. Odds of winning are determined by the total number of eligible entries received.
  8. Sponsors reserve the right, at its sole discretion, to disqualify anyone found to have tampered with the Contest.
  9. THE CONTEST IS OFFERED AND PARTICIPATION IS LIMITED TO ONLY RESIDENTS OF THE UNITED STATES, CANADA AND MEXICO.
  10. To be eligible, entrants must be eighteen (18) year of age or older.
  11. THERE IS NO ENTRY FEE.
  12. ENTRANTS DO NOT RECEIVE BY WAY OF OR UNDER THE CONTEST ANY INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS IN ANY COPYRIGHTS, PATENTS, TRADEMARKS, TRADE NAMES, TECHNOLOGY, TRADE SECRETS, OR KNOW-HOW OF TEXAS INSTRUMENTS OR ANY THIRD PARTY.
  13. Entrants must agree to these terms and conditions to be eligible to participate in this Contest. Entries must be submitted by the deadline to be considered. Entrants will not be allowed to change or supplement their submissions once they have been submitted.
  14. All entrants agree to follow and abide by the judging criteria.
  15. All entrants warrant and represent that the business card and/or Twitter handle is entirely original and that entrant is the owner of said business card and Twitter handle. This representation is a requirement of participation in the Contest. By submitting a business card or Twitter handle, all entrants represent and that there is no third party of any kind, whether an academic institution, commercial company, individual, or governmental legal entity which has any proprietary or other interest in, claims or rights to, any intellectual property rights, including trade secret, know-how, copyright, patent, trademark or trade name, in any material submitted under the Contest.
  16. All entrants agree, represent and guarantee that there are no obligations of any nature, legal or otherwise, which would prohibit, restrict, or interfere with their participation in the Contest or submission of their video content. All entrants agree to obtain any necessary clearance or approval from any necessary third party participation in all Contest activities and any such approvals, which are required as a condition of participation.
  17. No confidential relationship is established between TI and the entrant as a result of entering this Contest. None of the content submitted by the entrants will be treated by TI as trade secrets, confidential information, or as protected data under any obligation.
  18. Taxes (United States federal, state and local) and other obligations are solely the responsibility of the winners. Prizes may be subject to reporting for tax and other purposes. Winners agree to supply TI with any information necessary for tax reporting purposes and to cooperate in fulfilling all applicable legal requirements.
  19. The entrant whose business card is chosen for consideration for any award, as a condition of award, may be required to submit further information concerning employment and residence. Also, as a condition of award, the entrant may be required to sign a liability/publicity release.
  20. The non-exclusive license to Sponsors of intellectual property rights, as described herein, is free of charge and without remuneration of any kind. All entrants agree that the opportunity to compete for prizes and receive publicity represents full and adequate consideration for license of these rights by all entrants. Prizes do not represent fixed-sum monetary remuneration of the licensing of intellectual property.
  21. All entrants grant to Sponsors the right to publicize their names, likeness, any information provided on the business card in whatever manner without reservation or compensation. Entrants further agree to execute, at TIs request, a publicity release related to TIs use of an entrants name, likeness or information.
  22. Entrants will not be reimbursed for any costs incurred or for efforts expended in connection with their participation in the Contest. Such costs are the responsibility of the participants.
  23. NO PURCHASE IS NECESSARY.
  24. Decisions by the Contest judges are final. Sponsors reserve the right to refrain from awarding any prize if there are no or minimal qualified entries.
  25. PRIZES: The thirty (30) winners of the first and second phases of the contest will receive BeagleBone Black boards valued at $45 USD each or BeagleBone.org hats valued at $6 USD each, depending on the order in which their business cards were drawn. The first 15 drawn in each of the two phases of the contest will receive a hat and the second 15 drawn in each of the two phases of the contest will receive a BeagleBone Black board. Total approximate value of all prizes: $2,025.
  26. In the event of unavailability of any of the stated prizes, Sponsors reserves the right to substitute items of equal or greater value.
  27. If a winner cannot be reached by 4:00 p.m. (PDT) on April 25, 2013 Sponsors reserve the right to deem the prize forfeited.
  28. Employees and agents of Sponsors and such individuals immediate family (including spouse, children, parents, siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, step-children, step-parents and in-laws) and members of the same household are prohibited from entering this Contest.
  29. THE CONTEST SHALL BE CONSIDERED VOID WHERE, AND TO THE EXTENT, PROHIBITED BY LAW.
  30. Sponsors reserve the right to use information regarding contestants for future mailings subject to applicable laws and regulations and privacy policies. Texas Instruments privacy policy can be found at www.ti.com/home_f_privacy.
  31. Subject to verification of eligibility and compliance with all Contest rules, the first thirty (30) business cards drawn will be awarded Prizes during each of the two phases of the contest.
  32. No entries will be returned to participants, regardless of whether they are accepted. All business cards become the property of TI. The winners names will be published on Sponsors websites and media outlets.
  33. If there is a dispute regarding the identity of the entrant, Sponsors reserves the right to deem the account holder of the e-mail address as the entrant.
  34. THE CONTEST AND ITS RULES AND CONDITIONS SHALL BE GOVERNED BY THE LAWS OF THE STATE OF TEXAS AND ANY DISPUTE ARISING OUT OF THIS CONTEST SHALL BE BROUGHT IN, AND YOU HEREBY CONSENT TO EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION AND VENUE IN, THE FEDERAL DISTRICT COURTS SITTING IN DALLAS COUNTY, TEXAS.
  35. If any aspect of the Contest or any rule or condition be found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, illegal or void, participants agree to allow TI to change such provision and, upon notice, to make it valid. Also, in such case, the remaining Contest provisions shall remain in full force and effect and the Contest shall proceed accordingly.
  36. Phase 1 contest winners will be notified by Sponsors by 7:00 p.m. (PDT) on April 23, 2013. Phase 2 contest winners will be notified by Sponsors by 5:30 p.m. (PDT) on April 24, 2013. column12: USB-powered BeagleBoard features an OMAP3530 720MHz ARM Cortex-A8 processor

column11:
Software

There is no single collection of software for the Beagle Board and the board is not shipped with any operating system or application software. Instead, the Beagle Board runs many operating systems and applications coming from the community.

To find out about software for Beagle, search the project listings. The test software for the Beagle Board is available on code.google.com. Some software is also hosted on www.beagleboard.org
column12:
but be sure to check with project page to determine if you are pulling from the proper source.

Second Edition

November 2015
column14:
University of Wyoming
Jason Kridner
column15:
Texas Instruments

Abstract

BeagleBone Black is a low-cost
column16: open hardware computer uniquely suited to interact with sensors and actuators directly and over the Web. Introduced in April 2013 by BeagleBoard.org
column17: a community of developers first established in early 2008
column18: BeagleBone Black is used frequently to build vision-enabled robots
column21: and countless other do-it-yourself and professional projects. BeagleBone variants include the original BeagleBone and the newer BeagleBone Black
column23: super-scalar ARM Cortex A8 processor capable of running numerous mobile and desktop-capable operating systems
column24: typically variants of Linux including Debian
column25: Android
column27: BeagleBone is small enough to fit in a small mint tin box. The "Bone" may be used in a wide variety of projects from middle school science fair projects to senior design projects to first prototypes of very complex systems. Novice users may access the power of the Bone through the user-friendly BoneScript software
column28: experienced through a Web browser in most major operating systems
column31: or the Linux operating systems. Seasoned users may take full advantage of the Bone's power using the underlying Linux-based operating system
column32: a host of feature extension boards (Capes) and a wide variety of Linux community open source libraries. This book provides an introduction to this powerful computer and has been designed for a wide variety of users including the first time novice through the seasoned embedded system design professional. The book contains background theory on system operation coupled with many well-documented
column33: illustrative examples. Examples for novice users are centered on motivational
column34:
fun robot projects while advanced projects follow the theme of assistive technology and image-processing applications.

column11:
Fedora on BeagleBone Black

Doesn't open source software deserve open source hardware?

Did you know
column12:
BeagleBone Black already runs Fedora?

  • BeagleBoardFedora on eLinux.org wiki

BeagleBone Black is true open source hardware with every part available through everyday distributors in quantity one. The BeagleBoard.org Foundation is a non-profit and charges no royalties for the design materials
column13: all released under open licenses. Based on a super-scalar armv7    processor core (newer than ARM11) with ARM-standard vector processing extensions running at    1GHz
column14: BeagleBone Black fits in a mint tin and enables open source software    developers to show off without breaking their power budget---or their    piggy bank. Now at only $45 through distributors world-wide
column15:
shouldn't you be showing off on BeagleBone Black too?

If you are interested in advancing the state of Fedora on BeagleBone Black
column16:
let's talk! E-mail jkridner AT beagleboard DOT org.

Let's code!

Ready to start coding? Folks in the Fedora community already have Fedora running on BeagleBone Black and you can try it out.

  • Official project page - Link to the wiki that has information on where to download the current latest image.

The next steps include providing a USB-based flasher to avoid needing to work with microSD cards and bringing in the rest of the BeagleBone Black experience that will help new people get started with Fedora.

The BeagleBone Black experience

BeagleBone Black is a great way for developers who program for the web to get a first taste of hardware---and for many hardware hackers to get a first taste of Linux. To bridge these communities
column17:
it is important to have a solid first experience.

Elements of the desired experience

  • Web-based IDE - Cloud9 ships with the boards today
column18:
but the Adafruit IDE and codebender.cc solutions look very interesting.
  • BoneScript - A JavaScript library built on node.js along with the bone101 tutorial that utilizes remote procedure calls within the browser to become interactive
column19:
minimizing the effort to go from web programming to physical interactions with all sorts of sensors and actuators.
  • Python - The Adafruit Python library is rapidly growing along with libraries of demos on how to get started with physical computing in a popular first (and sometimes last) language.
  • Gcc
column23:
pkg-config and a bunch of libraries - Building simple applications in C/C++ should be simple!
  • Real-time patches - Not yet shipping in all distros
column24:
real-time performance is a critcal aspect for building physically interactive devices.
  • PRU support - The PRUs are 200MHz 32-bit microcontrollers within the on-board processor that are dedicated to real-time interface tasks--- supported by an open source assembler and a remote proc kernel interface
column25:
much work still needs to be done to utilize these processing elements that eliminate the need to add an Arduino or other real-time solutions.
  • Networking and file storage over USB - You shouldn't need to buy extra hardware to get started; everything in the box should be enough and it should be as self-documenting as possible.
  • Devicetree snippets for embedded interfaces and the devicetree compiler
  • USB-based eMMC flasher - All reflashing instructions today point people to write microSD cards
column26: but the processor can be bootloaded over USB        directly using the processor ROM---and entirely over libusb to make it        run on multiple operating systems
column27:
giving people who have never tried out Fedora a way to do so without altering their current system.

Much of the above is already included in the Angstrom Distribution
column28: in work    in the BeagleBoard.org Google Summer of Code projects or being executed    elsewhere. Having Fedora maintainers bring that experience to Fedora will    benefit Fedora
column29: BeagleBone Black users and even users of other low-cost    development platforms where much of the code can be shared
column30:
thanks to us all running Linux that abstracts all the low-level interfaces.

Where can delivering this experience lead?

With the right solutions
column31: Fedora could be established as the perferred    distribution for embedded developers and developers seeking to wrap some    plastic
column33:
lights and motors around their software solutions.

Interested?

Contact me at jkridner AT beagleboard DOT org

"

column11:
Boris at Linux World Expo 2008

See your picture with Boris on Flickr

BeagleBoard.org Mission Statement

Open Everywhere Computing for Everyone


Mission is Open Everywhere Computing

BeagleBoard.org seeks to foster the advancement of open source hardware and software for building embedded computing solutions at all skill levels.

Vision is Openness Enables Everyone

Open development means sharing the ability to reproduce a craft and providing a means for refining that craft. Individuals with less defined skills are able to fully observe the skills of others to refine their skills. Contributions of individuals are collected
column12:
advancing the ability of all individuals with the basic skills of the community.

Linux plays a critical role in this vision
column13: because no other software project has ever brought so many  collaborators together and run on so many platforms. For BeagleBoard.org to be successful
column14:
it means enabling Linux developers through support in the mainline Linux kernel such that all popular Linux distros can provide support for a viable everywhere-computing platform.

Because the mainline Linux maintainers demand that capabilities not be implemented for a single device if the capability exists on multiple devices
column15: the work that goes into the mainline kernel as a result of the BeagleBoard.org platforms is available for all platforms
column16:
making Linux more friendly for anyone using it on a everywhere-computing platform.

Skills and capabilities enabled by open everywhere computing

  • Interfacing sensors and controls
  • Programming
  • Networking
  • Device driver development
  • Operating system design and usage
  • Other general computer science and electrical engingeering concepts and usage
  • Collaboration

BeagleBone Black project spotlight:
GrowCubes

By Tara Stratton

Open-source technology is all about getting the power of technology into the hands of everyone. Thats why we at BeagleBoard.org really like the idea of GrowCubes stackable
column12: modular farming environments             that use mobile technology and aeroponics to grow delicious
column13: organic produce indoorsusing 90% less water. Developed by a team             at NYC Resistor (NYCR)
column14: GrowCubes democratize agriculture by placing             the power to grow back into the hands of individuals and             communities. Its based on the radical idea that food should be             healthy
column15: tasty and accessible to all
column16:  said Chris Beauvois
column17: founder             of GrowCubes. This idea of open-source agriculture has implications             not only for culinary culture
column18:
but for some of the urgent public health issues facing us today.

According to Chris
column19: developing GrowCubes was very challenging.            Aeroponics is a delicate process
column20: and we spent more than a year            developing our misting hardware alone. In addition to these            aeroponic spray misters
column21: the system also includes a network of            sensors and data from the Internet to give the system intel about            what each plant needs. With this information
column23:
ensuring plants get the best possible light.

GrowCubes are powered by BeagleBone Black. Chris and his team at NYCR chose BeagleBone Black for its high performance
column24: large GPIO             pin count and the added real-time performance of the programmable             real-time unit (PRU) within TIs Sitara AM335x processor.             BeagleBone Black is the most complete solution of any kind and is             especially suited to handling the complexities of our product
column25:
 said Chris.

Now that the NYCR team has its project complete
column26:
it plans to build a large run of GrowCubes to distribute to public schools in New York City.

GrowCubes is currently a contender in Engadgets Insert Coin: New Challengers competition
column27: where readers can vote for the most            promising crowd-funding hardware. Online voting starts at 5 p.m. EST            on Saturday
column28: Nov. 9 and ends at 4:30 p.m. on Sunday
column29: Nov. 10.            If you are inspired by what GrowCubes can do for agriculture in our            cities (or anywhere else for that matter)
column30:
consider voting for them here.

Want even more information about GrowCubes? The best place to start at the moment is this YouTube video. You can also check out Chris Beauvois interview with Mike Riggs at The Atlantic Cities blog. And lastly
column31: tune into MSNBC at 4 p.m. on Sunday
column32:
Nov. 10. Chris will be a featured guest!

"

column11:
USA Science & Engineering Festival

At the USA Science and Engineering Festival
column12: BeagleBoard.org will be    showing off a handful of BeagleBone Black based robots
column14: • QuickBot-MOOC v1
column15:
and
  • Beagle Huxley.

    • Each of these robots utilize BeagleBone Black
column16: an affordable open hardware computer running Linux with lots of specialized I/O for interacting with sensors and controllers for the physical world. They also feature a built-in tutorial and development environment for learning about connecting up these various sensors and controllers
column19:
motors and more.

Robotics Cape and BeagleMIP by Strawson Design

Inspiration is not an easy thing to come by
column20: and no one can predict     when it will strike. The light bulb suddenly flashes on overhead
column21: and the gears inside your brain start to turn. The excitement of     the Ah hah! moment is great
column22:
but often short lived when the realization of the logistics come into play.

Engineers often find themselves in this situation when a new idea for a robot pops into their head
column23: but then there is the complicated     process of crafting the internal hardware and writing the software     to actually make it work. James Strawson
column24: PhD student at the     University of California
column25: San Diego (UCSD) and founder of Strawson     Design
column26: grew tired of having to create new circuits for every new     robot that he worked on
column27: so he unified his current and future     robotics projects under one hardware and software platform
column28:
thus creating the Robotics Cape.

Robotics Cape by Strawson Design; image credit: Strawson Design

The Robotics Cape works with the BeagleBone Black
column29: powered by a TI Sitara processor
column30: to make a mobile robotics platform. It includes    2-cell lithium battery charging
column31: protection and monitoring circuitry   to make sure the robot is always charged and ready to play with.    The Robotics Cape also provides plug-and-play connectors to easily    interface with common components so you can build your robot without    soldering or messy wiring. It was obvious for James to choose    BeagleBone Black when picking a Linux development board. Strawson    said
column33: robotics projects typically require the    control board to interface with custom circuitry. BeagleBone Black    provides an enormous array of hardware interface pins for functions    such as GPIO
column37: etc.
column38:
which is exactly what tinkerers and prototypers need. BeagleBone Black is also a fantastically neat and tidy package that is ideal for tiny robots.

When creating the cape
column39: Strawson picked the features he felt would apply     to the largest number of applications. The cape offers:     <ul>        <li>9-axis IMU: Accelerometer
column41:
magnetometer
  • 6 PWM connectors to power servos or brushless ESCs
  • Power your BeagleBone with 5V 2A switching voltage regulator from 12v input or battery pack
  • 2 user-accessible buttons and 2 LEDs to test GPIO functionality and to test PRU GPIO
  • 2-cell lithium cell balancer and overvoltage protector
  • H-bridges to drive 6 DC motors (each 1.2A continuous
column44:
SPI
  • Range/gesture sensors
  • Serial GPS module
  • Spektrum RC receiver
  • Quadrature encoder inputs

    • Strawson first used the Robotics Cape to teach a senior embedded controls course at UCSD. Each student built their own BeagleMIP balancing robot based on the cape and was taught to design and implement a discrete-time controller to make the robot balance upright and drive. Texas Instruments University Program donated BeagleBone Black computers to UCSD to enable such a wonderful project. We learned a lot about implementing dynamic control systems in a Linux environment. I was pleased to teach fellow mechanical engineers how to dive into the world of embedded programming and circuit design
column45:
 Strawson said.

BeagleMIP balancing robot; image credit: Strawson Design

Strawson is working on a few refinements on the board layout and connectivity before bringing the Robotics Cape to market. He also looks forward to spending more time developing control systems with BeagleBone Black. He is testing a quadrotor controller based on the BeagleBone Black as well as a Robotics Cape Combination designed to be cheap and easy to repair while offering the networking capability and processing power of BeagleBone Black.

James Strawson demoing the BeagleMIP at CES 2014

The Robotics Cape is still a work in progress but will be available for sale in the coming months. For updated information on the Robotics Cape
column46:
visit Strawson Designs website at www.strawsondesign.com.

More info at machinekit.io.

column11:
BeagleBone Image Updater

This interactive page wizard will use the BoneScript server on your BeagleBone Black to download the latest BeagleBone Black software image onto a uSD card inserted in your BeagleBone Black uSD card slot. To do this
column12:
you will need to have your BeagleBone Black connected to the Internet and visible to the computer you are using to visit this web page.

This wizard currently requires you to connect your BeagleBone Black up to the Internet. The simplest way to do so is to put it on your home router via Ethernet. You'll then need to locate the board address via your router's DHCP logs or mDNS.

This script will write the selected image to your uSD card if you are running off of your on-board eMMC
column13: so be sure to insert a blank uSD card AFTER you finish booting up. If you boot off of a uSD card
column14:
you will write to the eMMC instead.

This script will write the selected image to your uSD card
column15:
so be sure the uSD card is blank or doesn't have any content you want to preserve.

This script will write the selected image to your on-board eMMC flash. If you'd prefer to program the uSD card
column16:
be sure to insert a blank uSD card AFTER you finish booting up.

When you type your board's address into the box below and click GO
column17: a script will        be copied onto your board to write images to your uSD cards.        The progress meter below will show you the status of the download.        When the uSD card has been written
column18:
your board will reboot automatically.

column11: Place holder. Plan to put all the boards under discover.

BeagleBoard

What is BeagleBoard?

The $125 MSRP
column12: USB-powered BeagleBoard features an OMAP3530 720MHz ARM Cortex-A8 processor
column13: NEON and VFP extensions for additional acceleration
column14: POWERVR graphics hardware
column15:
high-res video and the capability to stream with a portable media player. Work with all of the functionionality of a laptop in a single tiny package.

Processor: OMAP3530 720MHz ARM Cortex-A8

  • (>1GHz ARM11 MIPS)
  • NEON and VFP extensions for additional acceleration

Connectivity

  • USB 2.0 on-the-go (OTG) port
  • Connect standard peripherals to USB using any of the following:
    • A mini-A to standard-A cable adapter
    • DVI-D using an HDMI to DVI-D adapter
    • MMC/SD/SDIO connector enabling a complete desktop experience

Software Compatitbility

  • Angstrom (Open Embedded)
  • Debian
  • Ubuntu
  • Gentoo

BeagleBoard-xM

What is BeagleBoard-xM?

The $149 MSRP BeagleBoard-xM delivers with the help of its AM37x 1GHz ARM processor
column12: enabling hobbyists
column13: students and innovators to bring a project to development fast. Designed with community inputs in mind
column14: this open hardware design brings the previous generations' laptop-like performance and expandability to the next level
column15: while adhering to hand-held power levels. Direct connectivity is supported by the on-board four-port hub with 10/100 Ethernet
column16:
while maintaining a tiny credit-card-sized footprint.

Processor: AM37x 1GHz ARM Cortex-A8 compatible

  • More than 2
column17:
000 Dhrystone MIPS
  • Up to 20 million polygons/second graphics
  • HD video capable C64+TMDSP core
  • 512 MB LPDDR RAM

    • Connectivity

    • 2D/3D graphics accelerator
    • 4 USB 2.0 ports
    • MMC/SD connector
    • DVI-D port
    • S-Video port
    • USB mini AB connector
    • Ethernet

    Software Compatibility

    • Angstrom Linux
    • Android
    • Ubuntu
    • XBMC

column11:
BeagleBoard.org Logo Program

BeagleBoard Compliant

The product bearing the BeagleBoard Compliant Logo has been tested by BeagleBoard.org and has been determined to be BeagleBoard Compliant. BeagleBoard Compliant is defined as a product that (a) is identical in technical design and functionality as the specified BeagleBoard.org product with which this product is compliant
column12: and (b) runs on the version of the software provided by BeagleBoard.org to supplier. A product shall be deemed BeagleBoard Compliant as of the manufacture date. If additional peripherals are bundled with the suppliers product
column13:
the BeagleBoard Compliant certification does not extend to those peripherals.

This product may include other accessories and the applicability for use with this product is the sole responsibility of the supplier.

General support for this board is available from the BeagleBoard.org community. All hardware support for this product is the responsibility of the supplier. Return merchandise authorization support is provided by the supplier and access to this is provided by the supplier via its website.

The quality and the manufacture of products compliant with this Agreement are the sole responsibility of the supplier of this product and BeagleBoard.org bears no responsibility for the inability of the supplier of this product either to maintain this compliancy or to the quality of the product. BeagleBoard.org will make every effort to insure the continued compliance of this product by working with and supporting the supplier to the extent the supplier wishes to do so.

Current "beagleboard compliant" logo licensee(s):

  • Element14

BeagleBoard Compatible

The product bearing the BeagleBoard Compatible Logo has been tested by BeagleBoard.org and has been determined to be BeagleBoard Compatible. "BeagleBoard Compatible" is defined as a product that (a) runs on the version of the software provided by BeagleBoard.org to supplier
column14: (b) said software also runs on a BeagleBoard.org product
column15:
and (c) releases open hardware design materials. A product shall be deemed BeagleBoard Compliant as of the manufacture date.

This product may include other accessories and the applicability for use with this product is the sole responsibility of the supplier.

General support for this board is available from the BeagleBoard.org community. All hardware support for this product is the responsibility of the supplier. Return merchandise authorization support is provided by the supplier and access to this is provided by the supplier via its website.

The quality and the manufacture of products compliant with this Agreement are the sole responsibility of the supplier of this product and BeagleBoard.org bears no responsibility for the inability of the supplier of this product either to maintain this compliancy or to the quality of the product. BeagleBoard.org will make every effort to insure the continued compliance of this product by working with and supporting the supplier to the extent the supplier wishes to do so.

Current "beagleboard compatible" logo licensee(s):

  • SeeedStudio BeagleBone Grove
  • APIO
  • SanCloud BeagleBone Extreme
  • GHI BeagleBone Gadgeteer

Beagle Inside

The product bearing the Beagle Inside Logo has notified BeagleBoard.org and has been determined to be Beagle Inside Friendly. "Beagle Inside Friendly" is defined as a product where (a) the product maker utilizes BeagleBoard.org logo bearing hardware
column16:
(b) the product maker buys through approved disitributors and (c) the product maker is friendly to the community by notifying the BeagleBoard.org team of demand with sufficient notice to avoid disrupting board supply to the community. A maker of a "Beagle Inside Friendly" product will display the Beagle Inside Logo on their product information website.

  • OpenROV
  • Ninja Blocks
  • Thing Printer
  • Lasersaur
  • Carbide Labs Pick 'n Paste
  • Pour Steady
  • Squink

BeagleBoard.org released the first BeagleBoard
column14: an affordable
column15: open hardware computer in 2008. The original BeagleBoard continues to be available today
column16: along with the extra performance BeagleBoard-xM introduced in 2010 and the more maker-focused
column17: bare-bone credit card sized BeagleBone introduced in 2011. The latest
column18: most affordable and highly flexible design is BeagleBone Black
column19:
introduced in May of 2013.

The BeagleBoard.org Foundation is a US-based 501(c) non-profit corporation existing to:

  • Provide education around the design and use of open-source software and hardware
  • Foster communication between individuals interested in open-source software and hardware

BeagleBone Black

High-performance (1 GHz
column20: super-scalar) credit-card-sized ARM® Linux        computer has a low-cost design
column22:
integrated microcontrollers and ability to run on USB power making it the most affordable open-source development board around.

Capes are add-on boards that extend the functionality of BeagleBone Black to simplify the development of many common applications

Boston 2010

The ESC Boston 2010 Windows Compact Embedded 7 hands-on training with the BeagleBoard-xM was held on September 20-21. All of the materials are available for download from this link on MPC Data's website. My apologies for delays as Claus is on travel in Europe and did not provide the link right away (though he did upload the content).

Chicago 2010

Please download the class 4GB microSD card image from esc-20100610.tar.bz2. You can write it to your microSD card using a USB adapter on your PC under Linux using dd ' ( bzcat esc-20100610.tar.bz2 | dd of= /path/to/drive bs=8388608 ). Under Windows
column12:
you can decompress the image using 7-zip and write it to a microSD card using the graphical Ubuntu win32 image writer tool documented on the Ubuntu help wiki.

The slides are available for download below in PDF format. The missing ones should be uploaded soon as well.

BeagleBoard Sessions

  • ESC-104 BeagleBoard 101 (ppt)
  • ESC-114 Introduction to Native Embedded Linux Development
  • ESC-124 Booting Linux with U-boot (ppt)
  • ESC-144 GIT Started with Community Software
  • ESC-164 Lessons Learned to Build and Assemble Your Own
    BeagleBoard
  • ESC-184 Embedded Streaming Media with Gstreamer

    To install the example GStreamer pipeline scripts and related media files referenced in this presentation:

    • opkg install esc-gst
    • opkg install esc-media
  • ESC-204 Everything is a File
  • ESC-224 Qt on the Beagleboard Part 1  Basics
  • ESC-244 Qt on the Beagleboard Part 2 - Signals and Slots

This series introduces the new BeagleBoard-xM
column13: the latest version of the groundbreaking BeagleBoard. The xM builds upon the huge success of the BeagleBoard and directly addresses community requests with higher speeds
column14: more memory
column15: greater expansion capability
column16: and the incorporation of a 4-port USB hub and Ethernet.  Despite these changes
column17: the xM maintains binary compatibility with previous versions and continues to provide stellar performance at extremely low power levelslow enough to be run simply off of a typical personal computers USB portas well as a small footprint and an open hardware design.  The BeagleBoard-xM is configured to always boot from external media
column20: or USB port.  This series includes a demonstration and training image that includes the Angstrom Linux distribution.  The microSD card can easily be replaced with cards containing images of alternative operating systems
column24: or WinCE.  This will be the first opportunity for you to get your hands on an xM board.  Participants will receive their own BeagleBoard xM and an SD card that contains the distributions for the classes as well as demos
column25: tools
column26:
and more.

Classes in this track include instruction on embedded Linux
column29:
taught by experts in the field. These experts are also active members of the BeagleBoard community - come and join the discussion at http://beagleboard.org/. Be sure to pass on your special thanks to all of the highly active BeagleBoard.org community members for their contribution to this introduction to embedded systems development while you visit the community.

Student setup

Instructions will go here on how to setup for your classes. Please revisit frequently as instructions may be updated. Notifications of updates will go out to the BeagleBoard mailing list.

Serial adapters

It is quite helpful to have a serial connection. The BeagleBoard-xM can connect directly to a USB-to-serial adapter
column30:
so you are encouraged to have the required drivers installed to use a USB-to-serial adapter cable.

Optional Linux virtual host machine

Optional Android SDK

ESC France
column34:
December 3rd

Join BeagleBoard.org at ESC France for a hands-on interactive training workshop. You get access to industry expert led classes where you learn how to configure your kit onsite---and it's yours to keep!

Training and Free Hardware

Purchase your place now! Limited availability.

You can add a BeagleBoard to ANY ESC France registration package for 149 (vat inclusive).

Key Takeaways : Learn to boot
column36: and interact with a Beagle Board
column37: explore the capabilities
column38: develop with the boot-loader and kernel sources
column39:
and address the hardware manufacturing challenges.

Audience level : Introductory

Pre-requisites : Some knowledge of C compilers
column41: and the VIM or PICO text editors is beneficial
column42:
but not strictly required.

Presentation Abstract : This session will give you all of the hardware
column44: and kernel basics for getting started with development on your Beagle Board or product derived from the Beagle Board. A bit of Linux experience is desired before attending this session
column45: but is not strictly required. The attendee will be walked through the motivations behind the architecture of the Beagle Board
column46: how to engage with the Beagle Board developer community
column47:
and how to obtain and utilize the source code projects most fundamental to the board functionality.

Angtrom Demo from Windows

This page seeks to describe steps to make use of the pre-built Angstrom distribution mentioned in Koen's blog
column12:
but using only Windows. This is due to the fact that many people trying Beagle and Angstrom for the first time have not previously used Linux.

Use existing dd image to write the SD card

  1. Download dd for Windows from http://www.chrysocome.net/downloads/dd-0.5.zip
  2. Download compressed dd image from http://s3.amazonaws.com/beagle/angstrom-demo-20080917.img.gz
  3. Use gunzip or zcat to decompress the image and dd to write the image to the SD card
  4. From the Beagle u-boot prompt
column13: setup u-boot for booting kernel from uImage file on the first partition of the SD card and rootfs on the second partition on the SD card   <pre>setenv bootargs 'console=ttyS2
column14: 115200n8 console=tty0 root=/dev/mmcblk0p2 rootwait video=omapfb:vram:2M
column15:
vram:4M nohz=off'setenv bootcmd 'mmcinit;fatload mmc 0 84000000 uImage;bootm 84000000'saveenv

Resize dd image to use the rest of the card (currently broken)

  • Boot ramdisk 
    setenv bootargs 'console=ttyS2

column17:
32M nohz=off'setenv bootcmd 'mmcinit;fatload mmc 0 80300000 uImage;fatload mmc 0 81600000 angstrom-console-rd.gz;bootm 80300000'saveenv Hold user button and press reset

Build the 'dd' image if you don't already have it

  • Download MLO
column30:
and README.txt from http://www.angstrom-distribution.org/demo/beagleboard/
  • Download a working 32MB ramdisk image from http://jkridner.s3.amazonaws.com/angstrom-console-rd.gz
  • Search for other packages you might want to use at http://www.angstrom-distribution.org/repo/
  • Use HP utility to format the SD card. Details found at http://code.google.com/p/beagleboard/wiki/BeagleBootHwSetup
    Be sure to copy the MLO file first
column32:
then all of the other downloaded files.

    setenv bootargs 'console=ttyS2

column11:
Personas

Definitions

Persona characteristics

  • Community Participant - Loves attention and being part of something big
  • Tinkerer - Loves knowing how to do something cool
  • Underdog Fan - Loves to take on the big guys
  • Cheap - Loves to brag about getting the best deal
  • Freedom Crusader - Loves controlling their own destiny

Goals

  • Discover and buy a board
  • Learn how to use your board
  • Explore what others are doing with their boards
  • Collaborate with the community to improve the solutions

Personas

Allison

Allison heard about Beagle and is slightly curious. Allison

Brian

Candice

Don

Ellie

Frank

December Dog Dish

from the foundation
The Year of the Beagle

2014 has been an amazing year for BeagleBoard.org and BeagleBone Black
column156: the most successful open hardware computer ever invented. I know what you are thinking; "Jason
column157: didn't that board from the UK outsell BeagleBone Black?"                              Sure
column158:
but that board isn't open hardware: there aren't open source layout...

Read more »

articles


CircuitHub Simplifies Cape Assembly with Group Buys

By Jason Kridner

In last year's TI intern contest
column159: Max Thrun amazed us with his incredible video of the making of the GamingCape that turned a BeagleBone Black into a handheld-gaming console running on AAA batteries. If you are like me
column160: you immediately wanted one of your own. Max released all the design materials as open source
column161:
but actually building one 

Thanks to CircuitHub's new group buy campaign tool
column163: 000 on just a single board assembly
column164: we are each able to buy one for under $100! If more people buy them
column165: the price might even go down further
column166: so encourage your friends to buy one too. So
column167:
what are you waiting for? Head on over to the group buy campaign and turn your BeagleBone into a handheld gaming device too!

Read more »


hot off the presses

BeagleBone Black Interfacing: hardware and software

A highly practical guide to using Debian and Python

community topics

New Debian Release Candidate

Robert and other had been hard at work improving the default BeagleBone Black Debian image. He's got a new release ready for community feedback. There are quite a few improvements
column168: including a simple installer for Java
column170:
Dart language support and a simpler process for upgrading the kernel

Read more »


featured projects

Open qPCR - DNA Diagnostics for Everyone

Turning DNA into data just became affordable
column171: and biohacking will never be the same. This project is an open source Real-Time PCR Thermocycler
column172: a powerful technology that can detect foodborne contaminants like E. Coli and Listeria
column173: as well identify fraudulently labeled food products. It's used to diagnose infections such as HIV
column174:
Malaria and even Ebola. Chai Biotechnologies has recently completed a successful Kickstarter to launch building this device around BeagleBone Black.

More Details »


Pick 'n Paste - Desktop Circuit Assembly

Carbide Labs
column176: is developing a desktop circuit assembly tool that is enough to melt any maker's heart thanks to its capability to cut both the time and cost of a prototyping project. Not only does the Pick 'n Paste place components on an unpopulated board for you
column177: but it also goes one step further by applying solder paste
column178: which can be used to secure the components through a separate baking step. All you have to do is place your board and components in the work area
column179: input information about the prototype's design
column180:
perform a quick calibration and voila - your project is on its way to completion!

More Details »

Quarterly Dog Dish

from the foundation
The Year of the Beagle

2014 has been an amazing year for BeagleBoard.org and BeagleBone Black
column156: the most successful open hardware computer ever invented. I know what you are thinking; Jason
column157: didn't that board from the UK outsell BeagleBone Black?                              Sure
column158:
but that board isn't open hardware: there aren't open source layout...

articles


Machinekit Meetup

By Natalie Nelms

Standing in line for coffee
column160: boiling water  all things that only take a matter of minutes. What if building circuit boards were that easy and time efficient? At New York startup company BotFactory
column161:
devices print and assemble electronic circuit boards from your desktop in a matter of minutes. Creating electronic devices has never been easier.


hot off the presses

BeagleBone Black Interfacing: hardware and software

A highly practical guide to using Debian and Python

community topics

LUGRadio Live USA 2008

A few people got to play with Beagle at LugRadio Live USA 2008. One attendee even did a small write-up in Chinese on Beagle and what else he saw at LRL. There was quite a bit of interest from many people who have never thought of "embedded/ARM" development before. I was a bit more surprised by how many developers are getting more interested in solutions that allow them to embedded their solutions
column163: into many new places as                                can only be done with small
column164:
low-power devices and boards.

FPGA Meets CPU 
Use Your Imagination

The LOGI Bone is an FPGA development platform that has been optimized for use with the BeagleBone. The LOGI Bone/BeagleBone combination was designed with key design attributes in mind including ease of use
column165:
maximum expansion capability and low cost to performance ratio. The LOGI Bone creates a powerful and versatile digital canvas for users to create their imaginative digital designs.

January Dog Dish

from the foundation
Thought Leadership for Internet Things

BeagleBone Black takes a central role in many developers' approach to connecting devices to the Internet. This is mostly thanks to its high-quality support of Linux
column157: frequent use as a reference platform
column158: and extensive I/O capabilities.                                 Google's Dart language is running nicely now.                                Canonical announced support in Snappy Ubuntu Core for Internet Things.                                There is an uncountable number of available IoT frameworks.                                All these possible ways to shortcut your design keep getting shorter.                                Still
column159: learning all the relevant skills can still be rather time consuming.                                Fortunately
column160:
it is great to see thought leaders like Brian DeLacey with other technology enthusiasts around Cambridge and Boston explore how to fight through the mysteries of IoT in the most expedient way.

Read more »

articles


Declaring the Drought Over

By Jason Kridner

It was April last year when I wrote about how we were going to fix the board shortage. Demand and activity have only increased since then
column161: but the additional production capacity has paid off and there is now inventory of both the official BeagleBoard.org BeagleBone Black manufactured by CircuitCo and the logo-compliant BeagleBone Black manufactured by Element14 in every major region. In the US
column162:
major electronics retailers are stocking BeagleBone Black including a Make-produced getting started kit at Radio Shack and a $39.99 sale at Micro Center for most of this month.

Now that boards are out there
column163:
we can spend more time supporting efforts to promote getting the most out of them. The large number of books available now is really starting to help that. Read more to find out about some of the current promotions and get a link to the current list of available books.

Read more »


hot off the presses

Exploring BeagleBone: Tools and Techniques for Building with Embedded Linux

The missing software reference manual!

community topics

Backing up your on-board flash (eMMC)

The process of saving off the eMMC to duplicate on other boards has been a hot topic recently. For Robert's Debian images
column164: there's a simple script you can run. To clone arbitrary images
column165:
you can use a minimal Linux system with a script that runs at boot to clone the disk image to a file.

Read more »

Updated Debian image testing continues

Robert has been busy fixing issues and updating packages. We seem to be getting down to the last few items to update
column166:
so the release could be any day.

Read more »

column167:

featured projects

Erle-brain makes building robotics easier

Erle-brain is an open source hardware Linux autopilot for making drones. Not only does Erle-brain handle the flying issues; it runs on the Robot Operating System (ROS) and consists of a BeagleBone Black and a PixHawk Fire Cape. The brain also comes with a Debian image flashed and the latest ready-to-fly code.
More Details »


BeagleBone Black attachment gives LEGO MINDSTORMS EV3 a processing boost

LEGO® lovers and Makers rejoice! FATCATLAB has created a BeagleBone Black attachment for the MINDSTORMS EV3 modelthe EVB. This upgrade gives the newest version of MINDSTORMS monster processing power in an easy-to-use board.
More Details »
