February Dog Dish

from the foundation
Gearing up for Summer

I don't know about you
column156: but it was -10°F outside when I woke up this morning.                                None the less
column157: I'm feeling like summer is just around the corner.                                Before you know it
column158: we'll be heading back to Maker Faire Bay Area to see the latest in gear using tools like the FastBBP
column159: an open hardware manufacturing controller built around BeagleBone Black's design. We'll also be seeing what students can create by participating in Google Summer of Code. Perhaps a student will extend the prototype of a BeagleBone UI I spoke about last month into a complete electronics learning lab. The question is
column160:
what are you doing to gear up for Summer projects?

articles


Time for another Google Summer of Code

By Jason Kridner

Google started accepting applications for potential mentoring organizations on February 9th and stops accepting applications on February 20th. BeagleBoard.org has submitted an application. Your help is needed to make that application as strong as it can be!

Need some motivation and inspiration? Check out some of the cool projects that have been executed under BeagleBoard.org's mentorship under the Google Summer of Code in previous years. I've grouped them by some of the typical focus areas where BeagleBoard.org seeks to improve the status of open source software.

Read more »


How does BeagleBone Black compare to Raspberry Pi 2?

By Jason Kridner

As many of you might have heard
column161: Raspberry Pi launched their next board
column162:
the Raspberry Pi 2. There have been noticeable differences in the primary processor performance from the original Pi to Pi 2. This has cause a lot of people to revisit the question of how the BeagleBone Black compares to Raspberry Pi.

Read more »

hot off the presses

Learning BeagleBone

Hunyue Yau has been an active member of the BeagleBoard.org community from the earliest days. As an expert Linux consultant
column163:
he has a fair amount of expertise to share with BeagleBone users.


community topics

Driving SeeMeCNC Rostock Max v2 3D printer

John Oly and I spend a few hours this weekend putting together a SeeMeCNC Rostock Max v2 with BeagleBone Black and BeBoPr. We still have a few things to work out
column164:
but I wanted to jot down some notes here.

Read more »

Device Tree Quirks & the Beaglebone

Pantelis has continued to patch the mainline kernel to support the device tree features needed to support BeagleBone capes.

Read more »


events

Jason at Southern California Linux Expo - Feb 19-22 more »

element14 at embedded world booth 221
column165:
hall 5 - Feb 24-26 more »

Bring-a-hack at Pumping Station: One in Chicago - Feb 25 more »

3D printing with Machinekit at SE Michigan BeagleBone Users Group - Feb 26 more »

Midwest RepRap Fest - Mar 20-22 more »


featured projects

FSL Pegasus Touch

Did you know the Full Spectrum Laser Pegasus Touch stereolithography 3D printer is affordably built around BeagleBone Black?
More Details »


libpruio featured on Hackaday

Support for the programmable real-time units (PRUs) on BeagleBone Black is still under heavy development. Fortunately
column166:
there are some emerging examples that make using the PRU microcontrollers easier. The 'libpruio' project is an excellent one of those examples

With bindings for FreeBASIC and C
column167:
libpruio makes it easy for programmers to take advantage of the PRUs to perform real-time I/O using the on-board analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) and pulse-width modulators (PWMs). It is even possible to use the capture module to measure the frequency and duty-cycle of a pulse train.

The project includes all of the device tree configuration and PRU firmware
column168: so you don't need to worry about programming the PRU yourself. Just kick back and use the simple API and a good number of examples to get all your real-time I/O
column169:
without writing a Linux driver or using real-time kernel patches.

More Details »

March Dog Dish

from the foundation
Springing into Linux Based Machine Control

I recently spent a weekend with some of the most adventurous and inventive minds in the RepRap world at the Midwest RepRap Festival. Never heard of the RepRap community? RepRap was founded on the idea of self replicating manufacturing machines
column157:
you wouldn't likely have heard about 3D printing.

I demonstrated two BeagleBone Black projects at the event to illustrate machine control under Linux. The first was EVB
column158: a cape that enables use of LEGO MINDSTORMS motors and sensors. The second was Machinekit for 3D printing
column159:
the same software used in heavy industrial CNC mills. This breadth on one platform is unique to Beagle and a big part of why it continues to grow in popularity and enabling new open source projects.

Of course
column160: what I enjoyed speaking to the RepRap folks the most                             was the opportunity to teach others and bring them into the                             community. As I encouraged them
column162:
because there is still time to get involved to mentor students during Google's Summer of Code. We have a large number of applications to filter through and students anxious to start contributing to the state of open source machine control.

Read more about GSoC at bit.ly/bbgsoc

articles


Have a 3D printer? You can help a child this Spring!

Ja Staes has written an article in Detroit Daily about the upcoming Penguicon event as well as their support of the "Enabling The Future" group's effort to provide 3D printed prosthetics for children who have lost hands and wrists. If you own a 3D printer
column163: the members of the of Penguicon community are donating the raw material required to produce the prosthetics. Various sizes are requested to satisfy the needs of clinics with various flesh tones
column164: making the strategy of 3D printing the most reasonable approach at this time. Take a read of the article
column166:
print some hands and come out to this amazing event.

Debian Update Released
column169:
Some Users Look for Flasher

As of March 1st
column170: beagleboard.org/latest-images has been updated to a newer Debian image to encourage more users to try it out and provide feedback. Almost all of the feedback has been very positive
column171: but some users have had confusion because the image doesn't automatically re-flash the on-board eMMC. This is intentional to drive users to try the image out without altering the contents of their current on-board image. If you do want to write the image to your on-board flash
column172:
the rather simple process is discussed in this thread.

Numerous presentations at the annual Embedded Linux Conference spoke about the suitability of BeagleBone Black for many applications
column173:
including how it is "perfect for drones".

featured projects

FastBot BBP

A derivative of BeagleBone Black and Elias Bakken's Replicape
column174:
Truby Zong has released a Kickstarter project with an all-in-one 3D printer controller board starting at the crazy low price of $79.

Thanks to the programmable real-time units (PRUs) on the TI Sitara AM3358 and the Xenomai real-time kernel running on the ARM Cortex-A8 under Linux
column175: this all-in-one controller provides both fast
column176: predictable stepper                               motor control under complex geometries
column177: beyond cartesian and delta                               printer configurations
column178:
as well as networked-based printing and USB webcam based print monitoring.

Feel encouraged to back this Kickstarter and to request Truby to support Elias in the work he did to enable this project.

More Details »


BeagleBone Black in PADS

Mentor Graphics has released reference source for BeagleBone Black's design for their PADS PCB design software. This adds to the ports to Upverter and Altium
column179:
as well as the original source for Allegro.

More Details »
BeagleUAV: Linux drones

The Erle Robotics team has started a crowd-funding campaign on Indiegogo for their PixHawk Fire cape to turn BeagleBone Black into an Ubuntu-based unmanned aeriel vehicle.

What is SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green?

SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green(BBG) is a joint effort by BeagleBoard.org and Seeed Studio. It is based on the open-source hardware design of BeagleBone Black and developed into this differentiatedversion. The BBG has included two Grove connectors
column29:
making it easier to connect to the large family of Grove sensors. The on-board HDMI is removed tomake room for these Grove connectors.

Processor: AM335x 1GHz ARM® Cortex-A8

  • 512MB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit eMMC on-board flash storage
  • 3D graphics accelerator
  • NEON floating-point accelerator
  • 2x PRU 32-bit microcontrollers

Connectivity

  • USB client for power & communications
  • USB host
  • Ethernet
  • 2x 46 pin headers
  • 2x Grove connectors (I2C and UART)

Software Compatibility

  • Debian
  • Android
  • Ubuntu
  • Cloud9 IDE on Node.js w/ BoneScript library
  • plus much more

Order from Seeed Bazaar

Episode 110: Happiness is a Warm Puppy

Episode 60: Fun Things You Can Make Out of Beagles

Trade Show FAQs regarding BeagleBoard.org

Where do I find answers to frequently asked questions?

While beagleboard.org is the canonical source for information regardingthe Foundation
column12:
the eLinux wiki is intended to be the canonical resource forthe community to collaborate on frequently asked questions:

  • http://elinux.org/Beagleboard:BeagleBone_Black_FAQ

What is BeagleBoard.org and what makes that interesting?

  • BeagleBoard.org is a non-profit corporation
  • seeking to improve access to programming and electronics
column13:
• especially through open source collaboration with tools like Linux and Node.JS.

    • By taking a collaborative
column14: open source approach
column15: BeagleBoard.org enables    a broad ecosystem of partners and derived solutions in software
column16: hardware
column20:
websites and more.

What people do with BeagleBoard.org designs enables starting quickly and eliminating barriers as you move forward. We like to say BeagleBoard.org supports you going from "Kindergarten to Kickstarter".

What are you showing off at the booth today?

We are doing hands-on tutorials at noon and 2PM. The noon sessions is meant to be a bit more of a "first experience" and the 2PM sessions are intended for spending some hands-on time working on more advanced design challenges you might have.

We are showing off some of the real-time capabilities of the BeagleBone Black by demonstrating a 3D printer that is running Linux at the same time as providing real-time path-planning and stepper motor pulses. These capabilities are unique to the BeagleBone Black in this product space. The combination of Linux and real-time capabilities are also being shown off with the BeagleLogic logic analyzer
column21:
entirely done with software running off the off-the-shelf BeagleBone Black and open source software. BeagleLogic supports 14 channels at 100 megasamples per second and will analyze over 30 protocols.

Where can you buy BeagleBone Black?

BeagleBone Black is sold through a number of popular on-line distributors and brick-and-mortar retailers. For on-line distributors
column22:
see:
http://beagleboard.org/black.

What is the relationship between BeagleBoard.org and TexasInstruments
column23:
and why is TI at the BeagleBoard.org booth?

What is the relationship between BeagleBoard.org and Element14

How to get approved

There's no charge for being "BeagleBoard.org Approved"
column14: just a verification     that needs to happen. There's no promise your product will be approved
column15:
but we want people to know to use your product if it is of good quality and compatibility.

First
column16: you'll need to send samples of your product to Robert
column17:
Drew and Jason at a minimum so that they can test compatibility. Jason will send you shipping addresses and you can find his e-mail address on http://beagleboard.org/about. The product won't be returned because it will be used in testing future compatibility as well.

Second
column18: if any software is required to support your product
column19:
you'll need to make sure it is in the default images built by http://bit.ly/beagle-image-builder.

Finally
column20: you should wait to get a confirmation e-mail from jkridner at beagleboard.org    with a vector PDF of the logo for inclusion on your website

BeagleBoard-X15is the top performing
column12: mainline Linuxenabled
column13:
power-usersdream boardwith a core tailoredfor every computingtask and ahighspeedinterfacefor everyconnectivity need.Give your algorithmsroom to stretch!

Processor: TI AM5728 2×1.5-GHz ARM® Cortex-A15

  • 2GB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit eMMC on-board flash storage
  • 2D/3D graphics and video accelerators (GPUs)
  • 2×700-MHz C66 digital signal processors (DSPs)
  • 2×ARM Cortex-M4 microcontrollers (MCUs)
  • 4×32-bit programmable real-time units (PRUs)

Connectivity

  • 2×Gigabit Ethernet
  • 3×SuperSpeed USB 3.0 host
  • HighSpeed USB 2.0 client
  • eSATA (500mA)
  • full-size HDMI video output
  • microSD card slot
  • Stereo audio in and out
  • 4×60-pin headers with PCIe

What is SanCloud BeagleBone Enhanced?

SanCloud BeagleBone Enhanced is a joint effort by BeagleBoard.org and SanCloud. It is based on the open-source hardware design of BeagleBone Black with upgraded Ethernet speed (gigabit)
column23:
built-in sensors and a WiFi/Bluetooth option.

Processor: AM335x 1GHz ARM® Cortex-A8

  • 1GB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit eMMC on-board flash storage
  • 3D graphics accelerator
  • NEON floating-point accelerator
  • 2x PRU 32-bit microcontrollers

Connectivity

  • USB client for power & communications
  • 4x USB host
  • Gigabit Ethernet
  • 2x 46 pin headers

Software Compatibility

  • Debian
  • Android
  • Ubuntu
  • Cloud9 IDE on Node.js w/ BoneScript library
  • plus much more

BeagleBone® Blue

What is BeagleBone® Blue?

BeagleBone® Blue is an all-in-one Linux-based computer for robotics
column12: integrating onto a single small (3.5" x 2.15") board the Octavo OSD3358 microprocessortogether with wifi/bluetooth
column14: power regulation and state-of-charge LEDs for a 2-cell LiPo
column15: H-Bridges
column16: and discrete connectors for 4 DC motors+encoders
column18: and all of the commonly-needed buses for additionalperipherals in embedded applications. Fully open source and actively supported by a strongcommunity
column21: and rich set of robotics-oriented capabilities make building mobile robots with the Blue fast
column24:
and fun.

Processor: Octavo Systems OSD3358

  • AM335x 1GHz ARM® Cortex-A8 processor
  • 512MB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit eMMC flash storage
  • Integrated power management
  • 2×32-bit 200-MHz programmable real-time units (PRUs)
  • NEON floating-point accelerator
  • ARM Cortex-M3
  • USB2 client for power & communications
column25:
USB2 host
  • Programmed with Debian Linux

    • Connectivity and sensors

    • Battery support: 2-cell LiPo with balancing
column27:
Bluetooth 4.1 and BLE
  • Motor control: 8 6V servo out
column34:
2 user programmable buttons
  • Easy connect JST interfaces for adding additional buses and peripherals including:GPS
column37: SPI
column40:
3.3V GPIOs

Software Compatibility

  • ROS
column41:
ArduPilot
  • MATLAB and Simulink
  • LabVIEW
  • Cloud9 IDE on Node.js
  • Python

column11:
Embedded Systems Conference 2008

Silicon Valley 2009

Build Your Own Embedded System with the Beagle Board

Under Construction -- All presentations and SD contents will be uploaded here
column12:
along with instructions on programming the SD cards. This construction message will be removed once all of the content is here

This page summarizes the content presented at ESC 2008 in the Build Your Own Embedded System with the Beagle Board track. This page is still under construction and the content for most of the presentations
column14:
should be linked to from here. Please come back soon as this should probably be finished in the next week.

Instructions for booting the MontaVista-built SD card image provided with your boards can be found below.

The summary of courses can be found on the conference schedule. Below is the list of sessions and links to the materials:

  • [ESC-100] Beagle Board 101 (pre-conference workshop) - Gerald Coley and Jason Kridner
  • [ESC-201] Understanding Free and Open Source Licenses - William Gatliff
  • [ESC-221] Building an Embedded Linux System from Scratch - William Gatliff
  • [ESC-241] Understanding Linux Kernel Modules - William Gatliff
  • [ESC-261] Constructionist learning with Sugar and the Beagle Board - Bernie Innocenti
  • [ESC-301] BeagleBoard Platform BringUp - Bill Mar
  • [ESC-321] Embedded Streaming Media with GStreamer - Todd Fischer
  • [ESC-341] Introduction to creating 3D UI with Beagle Board - Diego Dompe
  • [ESC-401] Hardware lessons from building Beagle - Gerald Coley
  • [ESC-421] Taking advantage of Bluetooth for communications and more - Hunyue Yau
  • [ESC-441] Building blocks of Embedded Linux Power Management - William Gatliff
  • [ESC-461] Memory Subsystem Optimization - Mike McClimans and Bill Stafford

Booting the MV Linux SD card

Back to top

As shipped
column15: the Beagle Boards are not configured to boot the kernel and root file system on the SD cards
column16:
nor are the SD cards configured with a boot-loader that can be executed by holding the USER button. It is simple to configure the boot-loader loaded onto the Beagle Boards to boot the SD cards provided with the demo image that was generated using MontaVista Linux.

Please note that this is a demo card image that was built using MV Linux for the purpose of this training and does not fully represent what is available from MontaVista in support of the OMAP3530.

  1. Connect to the Beagle Board serial port. Adapters can be found on the hardware page. Basic instructions can be found in the System Reference Manual and also on the Beagle Board beginners page on the eLinux.org wiki.
  2. At the "OMAP3 beagleboard.org #" prompt
column17:
give the following commands: 
setenv bootcmd 'mmcinit;fatload mmc 0 80200000 uImage;bootm 80200000'saveenv
  • Remove power
column18: have the SD card and other system peripherals connected
column19:
apply power and you should get to the "login:" prompt. Be aware that the system will turn off the monitor due to inactivity and there is not a trivial way to disable this time-out. Pressing any key on the USB keyboard will bring the monitor output back on.

If you need to recreate your MV Linux SD card
column20: or you want to use a bootable card
column21:
you can make use of the MV Linux SD card image (please request from sales AT mvista.com). You'll need to use zcat or gunzip to decompress the image and dd to copy the image onto a 2GB SD card.

Be very careful when using dd not to overwrite the wrong drive

ESC-100: BeagleBoard 101

Back to top

Jason Kridner and Gerald Coley

  • Slides

This presentation walked through the process of developing with the Beagle Board and interacting with the community. Particular attention was given to the boot process to get the Angstrom and MontaVista demos running.

Angstrom Demo

The following steps should allow you to program the Angstrom demo into the NAND flash on your Beagle Board using a Windows PC with an SD card adapter and without the use of the serial port
column23:
or a Linux PC.

Step 1: Re-format an SD card to be boot-able

Information on formatting the SD cards
column24: putting your board back into factory conditions
column25: and testing the hardware functionality can be found at: BeagleBoardDiagnostics. Specifically
column26:
this utility can be used to format the SD cards: SP27213.exe.

It is important that the card be formated with a specific geometry and be marked bootable in the partition table. The HP SD card formatting utility has been shown to be reliable at doing this under Windows. Under Linux fdisk
column27:
specific geometries have been shown to work well.

Step 2: Download the Angstrom demo SD card contents

The following content files can be downloaded from this site:

  • MLO - This must be the first file copied to the SD. It is the file loaded by the ROM boot-loader and it loads u-boot.bin off of the SD card.
  • u-boot.bin - Hacked u-boot to read u-boot.img for command script from MMC/SD card first partition (/dev/mmcblk0p1)
column28:
rather than using the environment in the NAND flash.
  • u-boot.img - U-boot script that configures the environment in the NAND flash to boot from NAND and programs the Linux kernel into the flash.
  • uImage - The kernel to be used to boot the ramdisk.gz and rootfs.tgz root file systems on the Beagle.
  • ramdisk.gz - The RAMDISK console-only root file system that is loaded into RAM by booting from the SD card. It has been modified from the default Angstrom root file system to execute boot.sh from the first partition on the MMC/SD card (/media/mmcblk0p1).
  • boot.sh - These commands executed automatically by ramdisk.gz and are used to install the Angstrom demo on to the on-board flash.
  • rootfs.tgz - The root file system copied onto the JFFS2 partition (/media/mtdblock4) on the on-board NAND flash by boot.sh.
  • bootable.sh - This originally contained some commands to "fix-up" the MV Linux SD card
column30: it is recommended you simply configure the environment variables in flash to boot the SD card
column31:
rather than try to make the SD card itself bootable. This script has been modified to set the environment variables using the u-boot_fw.tgz executables and should only be run from within the Angstrom kernel as running it from the MV kernel has shown it to corrupt the NAND flash environment variables for some class attendees.
  • ignorenv.txt - This is the patch used to hack u-boot. The link to the source to which this patch applies is included in the presentation.
  • mkubootcmd - This is the script that builds the u-boot script files:
    • u-boot1.img
    • u-boot2.img
    • u-boot3.img
  • u-boot.tgz - The hacked u-boot sources described in the presentation.
  • u-boot_fw.tgz - The files built by Frank during the class to set the environment on the flash (mtd2) from within Angstrom Linux
column32:
rather than from the u-boot serial prompt.
  • copyfiles.bat - A DOS batch script file that you can edit to format the SD card and copy the files in the proper order. This script file calls itself again in the end for the purpose of making multiple SD cards.

    • Step 3: Copy files to the SD card

    All of the files should be copied to the SD card in order. At least the MLO file should be copied onto the SD card first
column33:
immediately after formatting the card.

Step 4: Install Angstrom demo by booting the SD card

Insert the SD card
column35:
and apply power. You can release the USER button when you see the USR0/USR1 LEDs come on (within a second from applying power). Type "yes" to install the demo and "flash" to configure the board to boot the demo upon startup.

Step 5: Configure for running MV Linux demo

Remove power
column37: then apply power again.  This time
column38:
do not hold the USER button and the SD card is not required to be inserted. You will boot to a GUI where you can login. The password is 'Angstrom'. Bring up a root shell and you can run the following commands to configure the board to boot to the MV Linux demo: 

fw_setenv bootcmd 'mmcinit;fatload mmc 0 80200000 uImage;bootm 80200000'

Shutdown and restart with the MV Linux demo SD card inserted and it will boot. You can then install the 3D graphics drivers and utilize other aspects of the demo.

Additional notes

If you have a serial port connection
column39: you can use configure the boot source from the u-boot console.  Press  when you see the text being output
column41:
to reach the prompt.

From the U-Boot prompt (OMAP3 beagleboard.org #) on the serial port
column42: if you have the Angstrom demo installed into the NAND flash
column43:
configure the Beagle Board to execute it with the following commands: 

setenv bootargs 'console=ttyS2
column44:
115200n8 console=tty0 root=/dev/mtdblock4 rw rootfstype=jffs2 nohz=off'setenv bootcmd 'nand read 80200000 280000 400000;bootm 80200000'saveenvboot

From the U-Boot prompt (OMAP3 beagleboard.org #) on the serial port
column45: to execute either the MV Linux demo or the Sugar demo stored on SD cards
column47:
115200n8 console=tty0 root=/dev/mmcblk0p2 rw rootwait nohz=off'setenv bootcmd 'mmcinit;fatload mmc 0 80200000 uImage;bootm 80200000'saveenvboot

During the class
column48: some attendees were running USB networking and VNC to use their laptops as the keyboard
column50: video
column51:
and networking for their Beagle Boards. Scott did a write-up on the Beagle Board mailing list on how to configure USB networking and VNC under Angstrom.

Additional source information to be provided upon request or sooner at this location.

February 2016 Dog Dish

from the foundation
BeagleBone Blue Update

Februrary is coming to a close today and I promised an update on BeagleBone Blue. I had some specific points in mind to announce
column156:
but it turns out we aren't quite ready to share these details yet.

One thing I can share is that Blue will have full WiFi and Bluetooth (including BLE) support. On prototypes
column157: we've been testing out the access point capability. This means that when you turn a Blue on
column158: it automatically shows up as a wireless hotspot to which you can connect your computer. From this            connection
column159:
you'll be able to use a web interface to connect to your existing WiFi network or simply create a new network to connect your robots! This code is showing up in the test repositories now.

Another fantastic bit of information I can share is that BeagleBoard.org has been accepted as a mentoring organization for Google Summer of Code 2016! Both BeagleBoard-X15 and BeagleBone Blue will be available for students and mentors for projects this summer.

Of course
column160: this month has many other amazing updates
column161: including a            Kickstarter from Bela.io to leverage the ultra-low audio latency             capabilities of BeagleBone
column162: updates on the Hackster.io SeeedStduio BealgeBone Green contest
column164:
including an open hardware design from MIT for rockets.

Want to get involved with BeagleBoard.org as part of Google Summer of Code and get early access to each of these new boards? Visit bit.ly/bbgsocideas.

What is Arrow BeagleBone Black Industrial?

Arrow BeagleBone Black Industrial(ABBBI) is a joint effort by BeagleBoard.org and Arrow. It is based on the open-source hardware design of BeagleBone Black and developed into this differentiatedversion. The ABBBI has support for an industrial temperature range of -40C to +85C.

Processor: AM335x 1GHz ARM® Cortex-A8

  • 512MB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit eMMC on-board flash storage
  • 3D graphics accelerator
  • NEON floating-point accelerator
  • 2x PRU 32-bit microcontrollers

Connectivity

  • USB client for power & communications
  • USB host
  • Ethernet
  • 2x 46 pin headers

Software Compatibility

  • Debian
  • Android
  • Ubuntu
  • Cloud9 IDE on Node.js w/ BoneScript library
  • plus much more

Order from Arrow

column11:
BeagleBone

What is BeagleBone?

Be sure to check out the BeagleBone Black which is available at a lower price and adds on-board HDMI and eMMC flash storage. Black removes the on-board USB JTAG and serial adapters.

BeagleBone is an $89 MSRP
column12: credit-card-sized Linux computer that connects to the Internet and runs software such as Android 4.0 and Ubuntu. With plenty of I/O and processing power for real-time analysis provided by an AM335x 720MHz ARM® processor
column13:
BeagleBone can be complemented with cape plug-in boards to augment functionality.

Processor: AM335x 720MHz ARM Cortex-A8

  • 256MB DDR2 RAM
  • 3D graphics accelerator
  • ARM Cortex-M3 for power management
  • 2x PRU 32-bit RISC CPUs

Connectivity

  • USB client: power
column14:
debug and device

  • Ethernet
  • 2x 46 pin headers

BeagleBoard.org® Trademark Usage Guidelines

 

The BeagleBoard.org® Foundation is dedicated to providingeducation in and promotion of the design and use of open-source software andhardware in embedded computing. As part of this
column39: firmware and/or operating system source code) and open-sourcehardware designs (e.g.
column40:
schematics and PCB layouts) for our devices.

 

The BeagleBoard.org® Foundation owns each of the trademarksshown below (the Trademarks). A license from the BeagleBoard.org® Foundationis required if you want to use any of these logos. License eligibilityrequirements are discussed in detail below. Please contact Christine Long (christi@beagleboard.org) if you are interested in obtaining a license and/or have anyquestions regarding these trademarks.

 

The Trademarks

 

The BeagleBoard.org logo:

Usage Restrictions

 

Third party use of the Trademarks is only permitted asindicated below. You may not use any of these trademarks without writtenapproval from the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation. 

 

Mark

Requirements

BeagleBoard.org (logo)

BeagleBoard.org (text)

 

These trademarks are reserved for official products of BeagleBoard.org®
column44:
and PocketBeagle® product families. Use of these trademarks is reserved for a select group of products and contractual partners of BeagleBoard.org®.

 

BeagleBoard (text)

The BeagleBoard trademark refers to a product family of BeagleBoard.org®. Use of this trademark is reserved for a select group of contractual partners of BeagleBoard.org® that manufacture/distribute the BeagleBoard® line of products.

 

BeagleBone (text)

The BeagleBone trademark refers to a product family of BeagleBoard.org®. Use of this trademark is reserved for a select group of contractual partners of BeagleBoard.org® that manufacture/distribute the BeagleBone® line of products.

 

PocketBeagle (text)

The PocketBeagle trademark refers to a product family of BeagleBoard.org®. Use of this trademark is reserved for a select group of contractual partners of BeagleBoard.org® that manufacture/distribute the PocketBeagle® line of products.

 

BeagleBoard Compliant logo

 

This trademark is intended for a circuit board that is manufactured using an un-modified version of an open-source hardware design for an official product of BeagleBoard.org® (e.g.
column47:
and PocketBeagle® product families). The product upon which a BeagleBoard Compliant circuit board is based will be referred to as the product of origin below.

 

For a circuit board to be eligible for a license for this trademark
column48:
the following requirements must be fulfilled:

- the circuit board is identical in technical design and functionality with the product of origin;

- the circuit board fully supports and ships with an installed copy of a version of software designated by the BeagleBoard.org Foundation for the product of origin;

- the circuit board has been tested by the BeagleBoard.org Foundation (or its designated representative(s)) and has passed the testing;

- all source code and hardware design for the circuit board must be released using one or more open source licenses approved by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation;

- you agree to indemnify and defend the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation against any claim arising out of the circuit board;

- you agree to be responsible for all hardware support of the circuit board
column49:
and to provide return merchandise authorization for the circuit board via your website; and

- you agree that the BeagleBoard Compliant logo will not be separately used with any peripherals without the express approval of the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation.

 

BeagleBoard Compatible (logo)

 

This trademark is intended for a circuit board that uses a modified version of an open-source hardware design for an official product of BeagleBoard.org® (e.g.
column50: a product from the BeagleBoard®
column52:
and PocketBeagle® product families). The product upon which a BeagleBoard Compatible circuit board is based will be referred to as a product of origin below.

 

For a circuit board to be eligible for a license for this trademark

column57:
and PocketBeagle® product families). The official BeagleBoard.org® product with which a BeagleBoard Approved peripheral device is intended to be used will be referred to as an accessorized product below.

 

For a peripheral device to be eligible for a license for this trademark
column58:
the following requirements must be fulfilled:

- the peripheral device has been determined by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation (or its designated representative(s)) to provide a satisfactory out-of-box experience for users for use with the accessorized product;

- if a license is granted for the peripheral device

What is SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green Wireless?

SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green Wireless(BBGW) is a joint effort by BeagleBoard.org and Seeed Studio. It is based on the open-source hardware design of BeagleBone Black and developed into this differentiatedversion. SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green Wireless has included a high-performance flexible WiFi/Bluetooth interface andtwo Grove connectors
column29:
making it easier to connect to the large family of Grove sensors. The on-board HDMI and Ethernet are removed tomake room for these wireless features and Grove connectors.

Processor: AM335x 1GHz ARM® Cortex-A8

  • 512MB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit eMMC on-board flash storage
  • 3D graphics accelerator
  • NEON floating-point accelerator
  • 2x PRU 32-bit microcontrollers

Connectivity

  • USB client for power & communications
  • USB host with 4-port hub
  • WiFi 802.11 b/g/n 2.4GHz
  • Bluetooth 4.1 with BLE
  • 2x 46 pin headers
  • 2x Grove connectors (I2C and UART)

Software Compatibility

  • Debian
  • Android
  • Ubuntu
  • Cloud9 IDE on Node.js w/ BoneScript library
  • plus much more

Order from Seeed Bazaar

BeagleBone® Blue

What is BeagleBone Blue?

BeagleBone® Blue is a complete
column12: Linux-enabled robotics computer. Community-supported and fully open-source
column14:
flexible networking and rich set of robotics-oriented peripherals make building mobile robots quick and affordable.

Processor: Octavo Systems OSD3358 1GHz ARM® Cortex-A8

  • 512MB DDR3 RAM
  • 4GB 8-bit on-board flash storage
  • 2×32-bit 200-MHz programmable real-time units (PRUs)
  • On-board flash programmed with Linux distribution

Connectivity and sensors

  • Battery: 2-cell LiPo support with balancing
column15:
9-18V charger input
  • Wireless: 802.11bgn
column16:
Bluetooth 4.1 and BLE
  • Motor control: 8 6V servo out
column19:
barometer

  • Other easy connect interfaces: GPS

Spring 2017 Dog Dish

from the foundation
BeagleBone Blue. Robots. Fast.

We were excited to launch a new BeagleBone last week at Embedded World: BeagleBone Blue is a complete
column156: Linux-enabled robotics computer. Community-supported and fully open-source
column158:
flexible networking and rich set of robotics-oriented peripherals make building mobile robots quick and affordable.

Learn more about the BeagleBone Blue in a quick board tour by Jason Kridner. Schematics
column159:
PCB layout and Bill of Materials for the BeagleBone Blue are available on GitHub.

BeagleBone Blue is available from Arrow
column160:
Element14 and Mouser. Compatible accessories such as robot chassis and cable assemblies are listed on the BeagleBone Blue wiki.

—Christine Long
column161:

Resource Links for the BeagleBoard

First off, there is a support wiki page for the BeagleBoard that includes System Technical Reference Manuals
column12:
Schematics and more.

Third Party Resources and Distributors

Consultants and Commercial Linux Providers

The TI processors wiki has a nice list of consultants and commercial Linux providers that support the BeagleBoard.org hardware

Hardware Distributors

Find a distributor for a BeagleBoard
column13:
BeagleBoard-xM and BeagleBone

Value added resellers

Special Computing offers unique products and services for the OMAP3530 BeagleBoard from custom cases and cabling to complete solutions.

Providers of OMAP35x in other development hardware

Several providers offer development platforms that utilize the OMAP35x that are either based on the BeagleBoard or otherwise provide some degree of software compatibility.

The Gumstix Overo series offers the BeagleBoard function in a smaller package
column14: adds more expansion options like LCD
column15:
Ethernet & Bluetooth and can be purchased in hundreds or thousands for commercial applications.

ISEE IGEPv2 Platform provides all the functionality of a BeagleBoard (65x93mm)
column16: completely industrial grade (40 + 85ºC) and includes Ethernet 10/100 Mb
column20:
Expansion Connectors and available in the thousands for commercial applications.

The KwikByte KBOC System Module provides easy-to-integrate OMAP35xBeagleBoard functionality and also supports simple expansion andcustomization at any volume.

TechNexion TAO-3530 System Module together with the inferno or thunder interface boards creates possibilities for developers to fully test all and more of Beagleboard functionality and start development of custom unique products immediately and without huge upfront investments.

Other OMAP3 boards.

Knowledgeable consultants and solution providers

QNX provides a complete solution for the accelerated development of automotive and general embedded applications with rich HMI and multimedia requirements.

ICS provides embedded software development services for the Beagleboard with focus on applications built with Qt
column21: a cross-platform application and UI framework from Nokia (formerly Trolltech). ICS is a Qt Certified Partner
column22:
and the largest independent firm specializing in Qt development.

Screaming Circuits delivers PCB Assembly service  prototypes and short run production. We guarantee turn-times as fast as 24 hours. We assemble Package-on-package
column25: microBGA
column26:
QFN and our minimum quantity is just one board. You can quote and order our pcb assembly service online.

LinuxLink Development Center for Beagle Board

ARM DS-5 development system

Booting MontaVista Linux 6 on the Beagle Board

Daughter-boards and accessories

The BeagleBuddy Zippy Ethernet Combo Board is an expansion board for the BeagleBoard that adds an Ethernet interface

column28: a battery backed-up Real Time Clock
column30:
and a I²C expansion interface (5V).

10 Years of BeagleBoard

from the foundation
Great Teaching Ideas Can Receive a Lab of PocketBeagle® boards



Let's Educate!
We are announcing a new program as part of our continued commitment to education in the use of open-source software and hardware. Educators in schools can apply for the opportunity to receive up to 30 PocketBeagle® boards from the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation. The donation of the boards will further project development in the classroom or makerspace. To participate in this opportunity submit a project idea to our online education project form. We look forward to hearing more about your ideas for using PocketBeagle® in the classroom.

Let's Celebrate!
Are you coming to MakerFaire NYC this month? The celebration of the BeagleBoard.org® community in it's tenth year continues by highlighting Makers! Join us for a #BringAHack event in the Big Apple on Friday
column156:
September 21st at 9pm at Leaf Bar and Lounge. Register to hold your place!
Can't make it in person? Tell us about your favorite BeagleBoard.org based Hack and be featured in our newsletter. It can be your own project or someone elses that has been memorable for you. We hope youll enjoy celebrating 10 years of BeagleBoard.org® with us!
Christine Long

column11:
The Beagle Breeds

Alternatives to the Digi-Key distributed OMAP3 Beagle Board

Because the Beagle Board is an open hardware project, it is only natural that derivative works that address various additional market needs would be born. This page attempts to summarize some of those alternatives.

OMAP3 Boards

The first place to look for alternatives is the list of OMAP3 boards on the TI OMAP wiki site.

Selection criteria

We are in the process of creating a comparison table and questionnaire. Below is the working list of questions:

  • What design and layout source available?
  • What volume and lead times options exist?
  • What commercial support sources available?
  • What are the distribution options and localities?
  • What are the additional interfaces and expansion options?
  • What interfaces removed or changed?
"

TRADEMARK RULES & BRAND GUIDELINES

General

The BeagleBoard.org® Foundation is dedicated to providing education in and promotion of the design and use of open-source software and hardware in embedded computing. As part of this
column186: firmware and/or operating system source code) and open-source hardware designs (e.g.
column187:
schematics and PCB layouts) for our devices.  The BeagleBoard.org® brand and trademarks belongs to the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation and include:

  1. The following logos:

“BeagleBoard.org” Logo

“BeagleBoard Embedded” Logo

“BeagleBoard Compatible” Logo

“BeagleBoard Approved” Logo

 If you use these logos in accordance with our guidelines and EPS and PNG version of the file can be downloaded here

  1. The words “BeagleBoard.org”
column190:
& “BeagleBone”

Acceptable use of the BeagleBoard.org® brand is outlined below.           

When to Use

  1. In connection with the sale and distribution of official BeagleBoard.org® products
  1. When used in this way the logo or trademark must link to our website www.beagleboard.org
  1. In a way that highlights your connection with BeagleBoard.org® such as referencing an accessory you’ve created for the BeagleBoard.org® product range

How NOT to use the brand

  1. In any way that would give the false impression you are endorsed by BeagleBoard.org® without prior consent
  2. Owning and using a domain names containing “BeagleBoard” or “BeagleBone”
  3. In a false or derogatory light
  4. To manufacture
column191:
sell or give away merchandise
  • In any way that will take advantage of our brand and reputation
  • In a similar but subtly different way
  • Associating the brand with false or counterfeit products

    • What else should I know?

    1. For non-BeagleBoard.org® materials
column192: if our brand is referenced your business name
column194:
and product should take the most prominent position
  • When referencing any of the official BeagleBoard.org® products
column196:
“BeagleBoard.org®” must always be included as the first part of the naming convention.  
  1. In this example the correct naming convention is “BeagleBoard.org® BeagleBone® Black”.
  1. Both “B”s in any registered version of the “BeagleBone” or “BeagleBoard” text should always be capitalized.
  2. “The” should never be used in front of any BeagleBoard.org® reference.  
  1. “The BeagleBoard.org® PocketBeagle” would be incorrect.  “BeagleBoard.org® PocketBeagle” is correct.

Logo

The following guidelines are examples specific to the BeagleBoard.org logo but apply to the BeagleBoard.org Embedded
column198:
and BeagleBoard.org Approved logos.

Minimum Sizing

The height must be a minimum of 12mm/45px

Spacing

spacing on all sides to ensure no interference with

Restrictions

Do not

  1. Rotate the logo
  2. Separate the dog image from “BeagleBoard.org®” text
  3. Change the color scheme
  4. Repositions elements of the logo
  5. Adjust sizing without proportional scale
  6. Add visual effects like shadows or gradients
  7. Add too or remove elements of the dog design

SUB BRANDS & PROGRAMS

To best enable collaboration within the community
column204: the BeagleBoard.org Foundation will authorize or license use of specific logos to suitable partners looking to advance solutions for participants within the community. We seek to hold our partners to the highest quality
column206:
and ethical standards.

Participation in any of the programs highlighted below will require prior approval by BeagleBoard.org.  To submit a request please fill out the form here.    

BeagleBoard.org® Compatible Program.

Partners in this program are licensed to manufacture and sell approved derivatives of BeagleBoard.org products under their own brand.  These products must run the community software and otherwise be have in a compatible manner where possible.  To join this program please fill out the request form here.

BeagleBoard.org® Approved Program.

Partners in this program are authorized to manufacture and sell peripheral devices for official products of BeagleBoard.org® under their own brand.   To join this program please fill out the request form here.

BeagleBoard.org® Embedded Program.  

Partners in this program are companies or individuals that use an official BeagleBoard.org® product as part of their design or end product.  To join this program please fill out the request form here.

BeagleBoard.org® Manufacturer Program.

Participating in this program represents the highest level of partnership with BeagleBoard.org®.  Partners in this program are licensed to manufacture and sell official BeagleBoard.org products.  

BeagleBoard.org® Embedded Program

What is it

Partners in this program are companies or individuals that use an official BeagleBoard.org® product as part of their design or end product.  Examples include using BeagleBoard.org® BeagleBone® Black as the embedded system in a gateway or industrial tablet.  Partners in this program will be authorized to use the BeagleBoard.org® Embedded logo on their product or product packaging.

How to join

Start by filling out the request form here. Note that you will need to include product images as part of the request.  Once submitted someone from the BeagleBoard.org® team will reach out to confirm whether or not you’ve been approved.    

Specific Branding Guidelines

  1. All guidelines for BeagleBoard.org®’s brand apply to participants of this program.  
  2. Principles of those guidelines apply to the use of the “BeagleBoard.org® Embedded” logo on your product packaging and product itself.
  3. Promotion and marketing of an embedded product must be done so under your brand referencing your association with the BeagleBoard.org Foundation through the Embedded program.

What products are part of this program today?

  1. Phenix Technologies

BeagleBoard.org® Compatible Program

What is it

Suppliers part of this program are interested in a licensing agreement with BeagleBoard.org® that will allow them to develop a derivative of an official BeagleBoard.org® product (e.g.
column209: and PocketBeagle® product families) under their own brand.  The BeagleBoard.org® team will support the supplier where appropriate throughout the development
column211:
and ongoing promotion of the product.  We are here to help ensure your success!

How to join

Start by filling out the request form here. Once you’ve submitted your request the BeagleBoard.org team will reach out to discuss next steps including establishing a license agreement to ensure the below T&Cs are met
column213:
and overall timeline for launch.  

Terms and Conditions

“BeagleBoard Compatible" is defined as a circuit board that:

  1. Is manufactured from a modified version of the hardware design of an official BeagleBoard.org® product
  2. Fully supports and ships with an installed copy of a version of software designated by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation for an official BeagleBoard.org® product
  3. Has been tested by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation (or its designated representative(s)) and has passed the testing;
  4. Includes source code and hardware design that is released using one or more open source licenses approved by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation

You also agree to indemnify and defend the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation against any claim arising out of the circuit board.  

Additionally
column214: while the BeagleBoard.org team will work with the supplier to ensure the products success
column215: all aspects of product ownership are the supplier’s sole responsibility.  These standards include
column216:
but are not limited to:

  1. Accessories (which we encourage!) and the applicability for use with this product
  2. Specific hardware support such as product failures
column218:
etc
  • Manufacturing and associated quality
  • Product compliance
  • An entry in our EEPROM database recorded in a Github-hosted readme.md file.

    • General support for a board in this program will be available from the BeageBoard.org® community specific and again
column219:
the BeagleBoard.org® team is here to help ensure the product’s success!

Specific Branding Guidelines

  1. All guidelines for BeagleBoard.org®’s brand apply to participants of this program.  
  2. Principles of those guidelines apply to the use of the “BeagleBoard.org® Compatible” logo
  3. This logo will not be separately used with any peripherals without the express approval of the BeagleBoard.org Foundation.
  4. Promotion and marketing of an approved product must be done so under your brand reference your association with the BeagleBoard.org Foundation
  1. As an example
column220:
you are NOT authorized to use any official BeagleBoard.org® logo on the product’s PCB silk screen

What products are part of this program today?

  1. SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green
  2. SeeedStudio BeagleBone Green Wireless
  3. SanCloud BeagleBone Enhanced

BeagleBoard.org® Approved Program

What is it

Partners in this program are authorized to manufacture and sell peripheral devices for official products of BeagleBoard.org®  (e.g.
column223:
and PocketBeagle® product families) under their own brand.   An example of a product in this program is the element14 LCD Display Cape.

How to join

Start by filling out the request form here. There's no charge for being "BeagleBoard.org Approved"
column224: just a verification that needs to happen. If your product is of good quality and compatibility
column225:
we want people to know to use it!

Once you’ve submitted your request the BeagleBoard.org team will reach out to review your proposal and ensure the following T&Cs are been met.

Terms and Conditions

For a peripheral device to be eligible for a license for this trademark
column226:
the below requirements must be fulfilled.  The official BeagleBoard.org® product with which a “BeagleBoard Approved” peripheral device is intended to be used will be referred to as an “accessorized product”:

  1. The peripheral device has been tested by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation (or its designated representative(s)) for use with the accessorized product and has passed the testing
  2. The peripheral device has been determined by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation (or its designated representative(s)) to provide a satisfactory “out-of-box” experience for users for use with the accessorized product
  3. All source code and/or hardware design for the peripheral device must be released using one or more open source licenses approved by the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation
  1. If any software is required to support your product
column227:
you'll also need to ensure its default image is built by http://bit.ly/beagle-image-builder.
  1. If a license is granted for the peripheral device
column228:
any future revised version of the peripheral device must be approved by BeagleBoard.org® before the “BeagleBoard.org Approved” logo may be used in connection with the revised version.

Specific Branding Guidelines

  1. All guidelines for BeagleBoard.org®’s brand apply to participants of this program.  
  2. Principles of those guidelines apply to the use of the “BeagleBoard.org® Approved” logo
  3. Promotion and marketing of an approved product must be done so under your brand reference your association with the BeagleBoard.org Foundation
  1. The element14 LCD Display Cape for BeagleBone® Black is a good example

What products are approved today?

  1. element14 LCD Display Cape for BeagleBone® Black
  2. Macchina M2 Adapter Board for PocketBeagle ®
  3. DINrPlate for BeagleBone® Black

BeagleBoard.org® Manufacturing Partners

What is it

Partners in this program will manufacture official BeagleBoard.org® products bearing the official BeagleBoard.org® branding.  Becoming a manufacturing partner represents the highest level of partnership and commitment to the BeagleBoard.org® Foundation.  Together we will work to shape the future of BeagleBoard.org® by introducing new products to the market and improving the costing and proposition of current ones.

How to join

If interested in becoming a manufacturing partner

please contact Christi Long directly.

What is BeagleBone® AI?

Built on the proven BeagleBoard.org® open source Linux approach
column21: BeagleBone® AI fills the gap between small SBCs and more powerful industrial computers. Based on the Texas Instruments AM5729
column22: developers have access to the powerful SoC with the ease of BeagleBone® Black header and mechanical compatibility. BeagleBone® AI makes it easy to explore how artificial intelligence (AI) can be used in everyday life via the TI C66x digital-signal-processor (DSP) cores and embedded-vision-engine (EVE) cores supported through an optimized TIDL machine learning OpenCL API with pre-installed tools. Focused on everyday automation in industrial
column23:
commercial and home applications.

Processor: Texas Instruments Sitara AM5729

  • Dual Arm® Cortex®-A15 microprocessor subsystem
  • 2 C66x floating-point VLIW DSPs
  • 2.5MB of on-chip L3 RAM
  • 2x dual Arm® Cortex®-M4 co-processors
  • 4x Embedded Vision Engines (EVEs)
  • 2x dual-core Programmable Real-Time Unit and Industrial Communication SubSystem (PRU-ICSS)
  • 2D-graphics accelerator (BB2D) subsystem
  • Dual-core PowerVR® SGX544 3D GPU
  • IVA-HD subsystem (4K @ 15fps encode and decode support for H.264
column24:
1080p60 for others)
  • more ...

    • Board Feature Highlights

    • BeagleBone Black mechanical and header compatibility
    • 1GB RAM and 16GB on-board eMMC flash with high-speed interface
    • USB type-C for power and superspeed dual-role controller; and USB type-A host
    • Gigabit Ethernet
column25: 2.4/5GHz WiFi
column26:
and Bluetooth
  • microHDMI
  • Zero-download out-of-box software experience with Debian GNU/Linux

Pico Projector Development Kit

Congratulations on your new DLP Pico Projector Development Kit. This is where you can find some demos to try it out with your BeagleBoard.

Initializing an SD card from a Linux host

You'll need a 2GB or greater SD card and an adapter that works with your Linux host to configure Linux on your BeagleBoard.

If you already have a Linux host

  1. Format the SD card, two alternatives.
    • Gparted method
    • Fdisk method
  2. Download the two SD partition images.
    • pico_sd_fat.tar.bz2.
    • pico_sd_ext3.tar.bz2.
  3. With the SD formatted and mounted on your Linux host

BeagleBoard Sponsored Projects Program

You can now register your project now at the contest homepage on eLinux.org for an opportunity to get a free board for your project development. Two (2) boards are being given away every week to those with the best project ideas as chosen by a team of community members. Those who execute well on their registered projects also have the opportunity to get an Always Innovating Touch Book or a Gumstix Palo43 system given away once a month.

Past contests

Software Design Contest #2
Contest is now completed and you can read about the winners on the contest homepage on eLinux.org.

Software Design Contest #1
Read about the winner of the first contest on robots.net and Linux Devices. You can learn about the other entries on the contest homepage on eLinux.org. You can also register your entry for a chance to win next month's contest.

column11:
Pico Projector Development Kit

Congratulations on your new DLP Pico Projector Development Kit. This is where you can find some demos to try it out with your Beagleboard.  Oh
column12:
you haven't bought one yet?  Here's how to get one .

The Pico projector can display the video output from the Beagleboard.  The Beagleboard needs to be configured in VGA display mode in order to interface to the Pico projector.  A VGA-based Beagleboard SD card configuration is available for download.  The SD card is configured with a video demo that starts when the Beagleboard completes booting up. 

Note: Currently
column13:
The SD cards and the instructions below for configuring an SD card are compatible with BeagleBoard versions up to version B5 only. An updated instruction set is in development with a planned availability date in late June.

Configure SD with partition images


Wait!!! OK so you don't want to configure the SD card yourself.  Alright
column14:
then contact our friends at Special Computing.  You can purchase a preconfigured SD card from Special Computing . If you obtain a preconfigured SD card then proceed to step 5 in the instructions below.

Proceeding to configure the SD card yourself.  You'll need a 2GB or greater SD card and an adapter that works with your Linux host to configure Linux on your Beagleboard.  The SD card needs to be formatted into a two-partition configuration and loaded with the images of preconfigured partitions.

 

If you already have a Linux host

  1. Format the SD card
column15:
two alternative methods.  Both methods assume a 2GB SD card.  If you're using a larger SD card then you can proportion the partitions in a similar ratio as in the examples.
  • Gparted method
  • Fdisk method
  • Download the two SD partition images.
    • pico-sd-fat.tar.bz2 ( alternate )
    • pico-sd-ext3.tar.bz2 ( alternate )
  • With the SD formatted and mounted on your Linux host
column16: extract    the partition images to the SD card.  The commands assume you're in the    directory where the image files reside otherwise type the full path    of the image file.  Replace /media/beagle_fat with your SD fat    partition mount point
column17:
same for /media/beagle_ext3.
  • sudo tar xvjf pico-sd-fat.tar.bz2 -C /media/beagle_fat
  • sudo tar xvjf pico-sd-ext3.tar.bz2 -C /media/beagle_ext3
  • Make sure you umount both SD card partitions once your SD card has been configured.
    • sudo umount /media/beagle_fat
    • sudo umount /media/beagle_ext3
  • Boot the Beagleboard with your newly formatted SD card.  You should see something like shown below in the TeraTerm display.  TeraTerm?

    Texas Instruments X-Loader 1.41
    Starting OS Bootloader...


    U-Boot 1.3.3 (Jul 10 2008 - 16:33:09)

    OMAP3530-GP rev 2

column11:
BEAGLEBOARD.ORG PRIVACY POLICY

BeagleBoard.org cares about your right to privacy. This policy explains how we intend to handle any personally identifying information you give us online. It does not apply to personally identifying information that we may collect offline. Personally identifying information is information that enables us to identify you, for example, your e-mail address, name, home phone number, etc.

How We Collect and Use Personally Identifying Information

You are welcome to visit BeagleBoard.org's web site while remaining anonymous and not revealing any personally identifying information. Sharing your personally identifying information is strictly voluntary. However, if you choose not to provide certain information, you may not be able to take advantage of many of BeagleBoard.orgs features and programs. The information you provide to BeagleBoard.org will better enable BeagleBoard.org community members to communicate with you regarding our products and your product needs.

Sharing your personally identifying information makes it easier for you to:

  • Request information or materials concerning our products and services.
  • Receive personalized newsletters and other messages on our products and services that we feel may be relevant to your interests, and generally facilitate future communication with you. By way of example, your BeagleBoard.org registration information and custom profile will be used to generate a personalized web page and to send you the BeagleBoard.org weekly e-mail newsletter, if you select that option, and from time to time also send you helpful e-mails about BeagleBoard.org products and service.
  • Purchase or license BeagleBoard.org products online.
  • Register your purchase so you can receive certain benefits.
  • Participate in online communities, such as discussion groups.
  • Participate in surveys or register to participate in a promotion (such as sweepstakes or contests).

In each of the instances above, for example, when you register with BeagleBoard.org, purchase products or participate in a survey, we may ask you to offer personally identifying information so that we may serve your needs.

To help BeagleBoard.org make our e-mail communications to you more useful, BeagleBoard.org may receive a confirmation notice when you open an e-mail from BeagleBoard.org and/or click on a link provided in an e-mail from BeagleBoard.org. BeagleBoard.org may use this confirmation information to provide additional information to you about BeagleBoard.orgs products and to enable BeagleBoard.org to better support your product needs.We also collect certain anonymous information that cannot be associated with you personally, such as the domains from which you visit us, the number of visitors to our web sites, browsing patterns and areas of interest. We analyze this data to assess trends, statistics and customers' needs, to help us improve our web sites, products and better serve our customers.

You May Opt Out at Any Time

You may opt out at any time. By way of example, when you are registered with BeagleBoard.org, enter our online stores or register for a contest or promotion you will have the option of choosing not to receive additional communications from BeagleBoard.org on our products and services that we feel may be of interest to you. If you choose to receive these additional communications and later change your mind, you may unsubscribe at any time. For example, e-mail messages will contain instructions on how to unsubscribe" from receiving the email in question.

The vast majority of TI web sites do not target and are not intended for children under the age of 13. column11:
BEAGLEBOARD.ORG PRIVACY POLICY

BeagleBoard.org cares about your right to privacy. This policy explains how we intend to handle any personally identifying information you give us online. It does not apply to personally identifying information that we may collect offline. Personally identifying information is information that enables us to identify you, for example, your e-mail address, name, home phone number, etc.

How We Collect and Use Personally Identifying Information

You are welcome to visit BeagleBoard.org's web site while remaining anonymous and not revealing any personally identifying information. Sharing your personally identifying information is strictly voluntary. However, if you choose not to provide certain information, you may not be able to take advantage of many of BeagleBoard.orgs features and programs. The information you provide to BeagleBoard.org will better enable BeagleBoard.org community members to communicate with you regarding our products and your product needs.

Sharing your personally identifying information makes it easier for you to:

  • Request information or materials concerning our products and services.
  • Receive personalized newsletters and other messages on our products and services that we feel may be relevant to your interests, and generally facilitate future communication with you. By way of example, your BeagleBoard.org registration information and custom profile will be used to generate a personalized web page and to send you the BeagleBoard.org weekly e-mail newsletter, if you select that option, and from time to time also send you helpful e-mails about BeagleBoard.org products and service.
  • Purchase or license BeagleBoard.org products online.
  • Register your purchase so you can receive certain benefits.
  • Participate in online communities, such as discussion groups.
  • Participate in surveys or register to participate in a promotion (such as sweepstakes or contests).

In each of the instances above, for example, when you register with BeagleBoard.org, purchase products or participate in a survey, we may ask you to offer personally identifying information so that we may serve your needs.

To help BeagleBoard.org make our e-mail communications to you more useful, BeagleBoard.org may receive a confirmation notice when you open an e-mail from BeagleBoard.org and/or click on a link provided in an e-mail from BeagleBoard.org. BeagleBoard.org may use this confirmation information to provide additional information to you about BeagleBoard.orgs products and to enable BeagleBoard.org to better support your product needs.We also collect certain anonymous information that cannot be associated with you personally, such as the domains from which you visit us, the number of visitors to our web sites, browsing patterns and areas of interest. We analyze this data to assess trends, statistics and customers' needs, to help us improve our web sites, products and better serve our customers.

column11:
BeagleBoard.org registration page

One of the missions of BeagleBoard.org is to create a website where anyone can participate, including taking all of the source of the website to create their own. If we were to maintain a long list of usernames and passwords on this site, there might be significant risk of someone using our open nature to hack into the site and steal that information. Besides, it is simply a pain to have to remember a username and password for every new site where you want to contribute. Still, we can't allow people to simply post whatever they want without maintaining some information about their identity, so we need something.

Fortunately, there is OpenID. Using OpenID
column12: you can maintain one username and password across the many sites supporting the standard
column13:
without needing to provide them with your password information.

Create an OpenID account

If you don't already have an OpenID account or a preferred provider
column14:
go ahead and sign up at wordpress.com and come back when you are done and visit the BeagleBoard.org login page to find out the next steps.

You can learn more about OpenID at SpreadOpenID.org.

You can verify your OpenID at OpenID Checkup by JanRain
column15:
Inc.

Patches to the website back-end should be submitted via git patches to the mailing list.

Wordpress.com is the only known reliable OpenID provider I know at this point. Google has removed their support for OpenID.
